Subject: Do you enjoy working with kids? Are you looking for a meaningful, in-person way to give back to the community?

If so, consider becoming a 5C Science Bus teacher! Science Bus teachers work to instill a passion for science in elementary students through engaging, interactive science lessons and experiments! Lessons are every Friday from 1-3pm; the lesson plans, experiment/class materials, and transportation to the school are provided.

Join our mailing list: https://tinyurl.com/5cscibus<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2F5cscibus&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cf77c95c157d0486d676c08d9aac27ecd%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637728574593248277%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000&sdata=O5vX7xr2mhICiq5vyqO%2F%2Bu8FuYUTnHb0bVk0vrHVDvQ%3D&reserved=0>

Do you want a clouty paid summer internship? Are you a first-gen and/or low-income woman?

Join PhelpsForward, a career development program aimed towards helping first-gen low-income women navigate the finance and fin-tech industry and help you find paid internships! Subject: Heirloom: Performance and Discussion with Sun Luu (Saturday, 4:30-6:30 @ QRC)

Join the Vietnamese Student Association on Saturday, November 20th at the QRC for a performance and discussion with Sun Luu, a queer Vietnamese-Chinese spoken word artist based in Los Angeles whose work revolves around themes of Chinese and Vietnamese heritage, sexuality, masculinity, and self.

This performance celebrates the launch of his debut spoken word album, Heirloom. It is a deep introspection of his family‚Äôs immigrant experience and his first generation upbringing, as told through personal narratives. Each piece is a musical slice of his life, compiling into an anthology of Vietnamese-Chinese celebration and generational reconciliation.

The reception will start at 4:30pm, with the performance and discussion starting at 5:00pm with time for Q+A and reflection afterwards until 6:30. Dinner will be served. Masks are required during the indoor performance. The performance can be viewed in person or live streamed. RVSP here: https://forms.gle/gPupLoCuhmtUNg6G8<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FgPupLoCuhmtUNg6G8&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cf77c95c157d0486d676c08d9aac27ecd%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637728574593308244%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000&sdata=GiO9jxMGS2xqAuB9wRhOYw1OmTiSgvAWL3AJF8z3XNc%3D&reserved=0>.

Subject: Get a Free Reusable Bottle: The Hive X Didomi

Come learn about the water crisis and get a free reusable water bottle this Friday, Nov. 19th, 12-2 at SCC South Lawn near Marston Quad.

Didomi is a social enterprise started by 5C students with the goal to provide water access through our reusable water bottles. Every bottle purchased provides 10 years of water access for someone in Africa who needs it the most.

Be one of the first 75 people to come and you will receive a free Did√≥mi x The Hive üêù Water Bottle.

Subject: Claremont SJP - Mohammed El-Kurd Talk!

Claremont SJP is so excited to announce that Mohammed el-Kurd will be joining us this Thursday, November 18th, for a conversation, poetry reading, and Q&A. Mohammed emerged as the face of #SaveSheikhJarrah, the global campaign to halt the eviction of Palestinians from the Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah earlier this year. He is the Palestine correspondent for the Nation, as well as the author of the poetry collection RIFQA, released in October 2021 by Haymarket Books.

Subject: Join PhelpsForward - Career Development Program for Women interested in Finance

Do you want a clouty paid summer internship? Are you a first-gen and/or low-income woman?

The program is 100% free and aimed towards current first years and sophomores. You don't have to know anything about finance to join! Subject: TODAY!

We'll be hosting a "DSLR Crash Course" this Thursday, Nov. 11 at 7pm. Come by to explore the space, meet some like-minded film folks, and get some hands-on training with our Canon DSLR cameras. Subject: Black Water Sister: Guilt Free Book Club

November 18 @ 6:15 pm - 7:30 pm
The guilt-free book club invites members of the 5C community to learn about the intersection of gender, sexuality, and the Asian/Southeast Asian diaspora through reading Zen Cho's latest fantasy novel Black Water Sister. No need to read the book in advance! Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents Writing for General-Interest Magazines

Tues, Nov 30 | 4:30pm | The Benton Museum Pavilion
Pomona students are invited to join us as we welcome Lenika Cruz, senior editor of culture at "The Atlantic," to discuss writing, pitching a story, working with an editor, and other insider tips for publishing with public-facing outlets such as "The Atlantic" and "The New Yorker." The conversation will be followed by a Q&A. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series of workshops and resources for carrying humanities scholarship beyond campus.

Have you been to physical therapy? Share your experiences and help me conduct research for an anthropology class by participating in a 60-90-minute focus group. Subject: Claremont Humans vs.

This semester's game of Humans vs Zombies will be held Nov 16 - Nov 20. Humans vs Zombies is a week-long game of apocalypse-themed tag played across the 5Cs. Zombie players chase human players to infect them by tagging them, while humans defend themselves by stunning zombies with balled up socks! You can sign up online at tinyurl.com/hvzfa21 or outside the dining halls at dinner the week prior to play, which happens to be this week!

Subject: Houselessness and Hunger Initiatives (HHI) - Film Screening: Streetwise (Thursday, November 11, 7-9PM at SCC Rose Hills Theatre)

Join HHI for a screening of the critically acclaimed documentary Streetwise (1984), which captures a deeply intimate portrait of houselessness in 1980s Seattle. Born from a Life magazine expos√© on what was believed to be the "most livable city in America'' at the time, the film follows the perspectives of young folks whose stories and messages still resonate today.

*While not graphic, the film addresses sensitive topics that viewers may find uncomfortable and/or triggering. Email FMI.

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents "Protests, Movement-Making & Radical Futures" with Juan De Lara

Thurs, Nov 4 | 4:30pm | Argue Auditorium

More from our Movement(s) Speakers Series! In this talk, Juan De Lara uses labor and environmental protests to examine how the movement of goods, capital & people produced a contested political terrain in Inland SoCal at the beginning of the 21st century. More generally, De Lara is interested in discussing how protest is a way to enact ideas or to perform political consciousness. Join us for the presentation & Q&A. More info at: bit.ly/delaraatpomona
\Terminate\

Regardless of whether you know much about tea, or even like tea to begin with, you're also welcome to simply study, meet others, practice calligraphy with Calligraphy Club, or just coexist in the space. As always, cups will be provided, but you're highly encouraged to bring your own if possible :^)
\Terminate\
Subject: Weekly Buddhism Meeting (Sunday, 9-10 AM @ Estella Outdoor Classroom)

After a long period in hibernation, we're happy to say that we're reinitiating our weekly meetings :) Centered around freeform discussions followed by short guided meditations, these meetings are open to anyone who'd like to learn more about Buddhism or anything related to it, so no prior knowledge is required-we only ask that you bring an open mind. Feel free to bring a friend or two, and to stay as long as you'd like.

Subject: Focus group on physical therapy experiences

Have you experienced an injury and have you gone to physical therapy for it? Share your perspective and help me conduct my research for an anthropology course by participating in a 60-90-minute focus group. I am interested in exploring themes of identity, individuality, pain, and strength. All findings will be anonymized and I'd greatly appreciate your help! Oh, and snacks will be provided. Fill out this google form to sign-up: https://forms.gle/YKAGjNR6JhGEfrew8<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FYKAGjNR6JhGEfrew8&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C7917a4d652624afaa16908d99fb920f9%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637716439729503233%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=HyFLZMUoOD7n0vZNWU4dmzJ2QpMS3FJKfXK%2FcofROQ8%3D&reserved=0>

-          pads (in various absorbency levels/sizes)

-          tampons (in various absorbency levels/sizes)

-          toothbrushes (individually packaged preferred)

*We use both travel and full size items

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents - "Protests, Movement-Making & Radical Futures" with Juan De Lara

Thurs, Nov 4 | 4:30pm | Argue Auditorium

More from our Movement(s) Speakers Series! In this talk, Juan De Lara uses labor and environmental protests to examine how the movement of goods, capital & people produced a contested political terrain in Inland SoCal at the beginning of the 21st century. More generally, De Lara is interested in discussing how protest is a way to enact ideas or to perform political consciousness. Join us for the presentation & Q&A. More info at: bit.ly/delaraatpomona

Subject: East Asian Political Society - Days Before the Dawn: The History of Protest in Hong Kong

Trevor Klein (CMC '24) will be presenting on his process of producing his documentary on the 2019 Hong Kong Protests on November 3rd (next Wed) from 8-9 pm in Edmunds 114.
His documentary was nominated and awarded in: Tokyo International Short, Seoul International Short, Anthem, Portland, Roma Short, Black Hills, Free Speech, and New Wave Film Festivals. Come by to learn more about his year-long experience and Q&A afterwards.

If you have questions, email us at: eapoliticalsoc@gmail.com<mailto:eapoliticalsoc@gmail.com>

Subject: Opens Tonight: The Green Room's Alice Won't Die

Alice Won't Die (by Grace Tomblin Marca, SC '22) is a dark comedy centered around the reunion of two former contract killers and their love, friendship, and deep desire to murder one another. It is about forgiveness, betrayal, and the morality of revenge. It's a wild ride, complete with a car chase, pepper spray, light choking, and of course, murder. Think 'In Bruges' meets 'Killing Eve'.

Subject: New Club: 5C On the Spectrum!

Do you identify as having Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) or are an advocate/ally of those with ASD? 5C On the Spectrum is a new club for students at the Claremont Colleges dedicated to fostering community, dialogue, and support for students on the autism spectrum. Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents "Protests, Movement-Making & Radical Futures" with Juan De Lara

Thurs, Nov 4 | 4:30pm | Argue Auditorium

More from our Movement(s) Speakers Series! In this talk, Juan De Lara uses labor and environmental protests to examine how the movement of goods, capital & people produced a contested political terrain in Inland SoCal at the beginning of the 21st century. More generally, De Lara is interested in discussing how protest is a way to enact ideas or to perform political consciousness. Join us for the presentation & Q&A. More info at: bit.ly/delaraatpomona

Subject: Come See Alice Won't Die, The Green Room's First Production of the Year!

Alice Won't Die (by Grace Tomblin Marca, SC '22) is a dark comedy centered around the reunion of two former contract killers and their love, friendship, and deep desire to murder one another. It is about forgiveness, betrayal, and the morality of revenge. It's a wild ride, complete with a car chase, pepper spray, light choking, and of course, murder. Think 'In Bruges' meets 'Killing Eve'.

Subject: Oldenborg - OLC Climate Change Theatre Action ~ Join Us!

October 25, 1:30-2:30pm / Rose Hills Theatre

What can theatre offer to the climate conversation? How might it foster greater engagement with the climate crisis? Launched in 2015, Climate Change Theatre Action proposes a model of global artistic engagement that brings communities together around shared values and encourages local and global action.

Presented by Oldenborg in collaboration with the Theatre Department at Pomona College

Subject: The QSC is open for one on one help with courses including: biology, chemistry, computer science, economics, environmental analysis, math, neuroscience, physics, psychology, and more!

Subject: The QSC is hiring partners for CHEM 115 and CS 62

The Quantitative Skills Center (QSC) is hiring QSC Partners (peer-tutors) for CHEM 115 (biochemistry) and CS 62 (data structures and advanced programming). Subject: Classics Render unto Galen the Things that are Caesar's!

Glen Cooper (BYU, College of the Humanities)
Monday, October 25, 4:30-6:00 pm

This paper examines the "body politic" metaphor as it was used by three thinkers: Ibn Sina (d.1037), Michael Psellos (d.1078), and Anna Komnene (d.1153), in their writings on medicine, philosophy, and history.

Subject: Agave Review Fall 2021 Issue Theme: UNCANNY

Agave Review, a 7C literary and art journal, is announcing our fall issue theme: UNCANNY.

This October, we are looking for art and literature that makes your skin crawl. How does a piece unsettle its audience, with or without the bells and whistles of Hollywood gore? Agave Review is seeking pieces that explore the uncanny-a moment or object that seems familiar but on closer inspection is anything but. Submit here: https://www.agave-review.com/submit.html<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.agave-review.com%2Fsubmit.html&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cd5fb3e76183c4511eda108d98f34277e%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637698276433184688%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=rJ5OTyM4LyNas6S%2F1IGHkOgn0JIED0tMd8ktqnLFRTo%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Ordering from Amazon? Try having your package delivered to an Amazon Locker

Pomona College has two Amazon Lockers on campus. One is by the north entrance of Frary Dining Hall and the other is outside of the entrance to Frank Dining. Simply add the locker as one of your saved addresses, then choose that address when you order your next Amazon Package. The lockers receive deliveries 7 days a week and you can pick up 24/7.

Subject: Have you seen a broken sprinkler?

If you're walking on campus and see a broken or misaligned sprinkler, you can report it directly to Facilities: http://workorder.pomona.edu/. Your eyes are a huge help in saving water at Pomona. Thank you!

Subject: OLC Climate Change Theatre Action ~ Join Us!

Monday, October 25  | 1:30 to 2:30 p.m.
Rose Hills Theatre, Smith Campus Center

What can theatre offer to the climate conversation? How might it foster greater engagement with the climate crisis? Launched in 2015, Climate Change Theatre Action proposes a model of global artistic engagement that brings communities together around shared values and encourages local and global action. The Asian American Mentor Program is hosting Untold Stories next month! We are OPEN for art submissions centering APIDA artists, writers, performers -- creators of all types! You do NOT need to have any art background to submit. Whether it be poetry, short stories, photos, music, journal entries, choreography, or anything else that represents your personal narrative, all works are welcome and highly appreciated. Submissions close 11/7.

Submit your work here: https://tinyurl.com/untoldstories2021<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Funtoldstories2021&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C203a2f37807747fe15c108d98cd3c1a3%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637695663368315245%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=B%2F8v2edp%2BK%2BvBzq4pJL%2FzLZ%2BRh79r3yufeIb9MPauFU%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Submissions Open for Agave Review's Fall 2021 Issue

Agave Review, a 7C literary and art journal, is accepting submissions for the Fall 2021 Issue; submissions window closes November 1. Poetry, prose (fiction, nonfiction), criticisms (film, art, theatre), and art-we'd love to review your work! The theme for this issue: UNCANNY.

Follow us on Instagram @5cagavereview to stay tapped into submission deadline updates, Agave Review upcoming events, and the creative work of your peers.

Subject: Do you enjoy working with children? Do you want to help host events meant to bring joy to kids in pediatric care?

If so, consider joining Project Sunshine! Project Sunshine is a nonprofit organization with a network of college chapters whose volunteers create and deliver free educational, recreational, and social programming to hospitalized pediatric patients. If you're interested, please apply through the link below by Sunday, October 17th at 11:59pm.


The Humanities Studio Presents Tom Lin '18 Book Reading & Signing - TODAY!

TODAY! Mon, Oct 11 | 4:30 p.m. | Crookshank, Ena Thompson Room

Pomona alum Tom Lin '18 returns to campus to read a selection from his debut novel, "The Thousand Crimes of Ming Tsu" followed by a Q&A and book signing. Huntley Bookstore will have copies for sale. A graduate of Pomona, Lin is now a PhD in Literature at UC Davis, focusing on the intersections of science, technology, and speculative fiction. The event, co-sponsored by the English Dept, is free & open to 7C students. Masks required.

Subject: Sagehens Abroad: Student Stories From Around the World (Study Abroad Podcast) Episode 5
Tune in as host Lindsay Chu '21, a History major, interviews Jacob Noh '21, also a History major, about his time studying at Yonsei University on the CIEE Arts and Sciences Program in Seoul, Korea. Lindsay and Jacob have a lively conversation about deepening their language skills, culture shock and adjustment, and exploring their identities as Asian-Americans studying in Asia.

Subject: Join Budding Branches and Help Bring Equity to the College Process!

We are a nonprofit run by college students dedicated to helping underprivileged high schoolers learn more about their colleges of interest and find their right fit. Many high schoolers do not have adequate support networks available to them during the college application process. Budding Branches helps these students by connecting them with volunteers at different colleges nationwide. To view our flyer go here (tinyurl.com/ezc8zj5z) and to apply go here (https://tinyurl.com/bnvaesj2<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fbnvaesj2&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C06919906b2d445d537ab08d989b8008e%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637692245677941581%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=69mPIlrH%2Byor%2FptF4XBZXOmLTfpRLv%2BdOF1LY0iFKuY%3D&reserved=0>).
\Terminate\
Subject: Join the Awesome Ladies in Physics & Astronomy (ALPhA)!

ALPhA hosts weekly lunches and other events that create a space for women (+ non-binary folks, etc.) interested in physics. Our goals are to build a community and safe space for marginalized gender identities within these fields. Our first lunch will be this Friday (10/08) at 12:00 in the physics courtyard (bring your own lunch or green box), and will continue weekly on Fridays. We'd love to meet you!

RSVP for free boba at our first lunch or to be added to the listserv: bit.ly/phys-alpha
\Terminate\
Subject: Join PhelpsForward - Career Development Program for Women interested in Finance

Do you want a clouty paid summer internship? Are you a first-gen and/or low-income woman?

Join PhelpsForward, a career development program aimed towards helping first-gen low-income women navigate the finance and fin-tech industry and help you find paid internships! The program is 100% free and aimed towards current first years and sophomores. You don't have to know anything about finance to join! If interested or if you have any questions please email me!

Subject: AAMP Impact Committee - Monthly Book Club Events on "Go Home!

Join AAMP Impact Committee on OCTOBER 10TH for a Book Club discussion on selections from the anthology, "GO HOME!" Selections are written by Asian diasporic writers who grapple with the idea of identity and home through fiction, memoir, and poetry.

The discussion will be at 4-5 pm @ Walker Beach and Impact will continue to host monthly events to discuss chosen selections on Nov 7th and Dec 5th. Subject: 5C Artist Coalition - Blind Contour Dates with 5C Art Co.

Hello All! We're excited to invite you to join us Oct. 8th from 6-7 for Blind Contour Dates. This is a fun opportunity to get to know others, make friends, and get to know the friends you already have a little more with crafts. You'll be able to paint contour drawings of others while getting to know them through lightly intimate questions. We'll have crafts supplies provided along with music and snacks. Hope to see you there!

Subject: Pomona College Department of Theater and Dance - Circle Mirror Transformation OPENS THIS THURSDAY

When five lost people meet in a community acting class, they learn about themselves and each other through a series of exercises and games. The perfect show to "start again" onstage, Circle Mirror Transformation is a ballet of humanity that promises to stick with you long after. Counting to ten can be harder than you think.

October 7th-10th in the Allen Theatre

Follow @5Cperformingarts on Instagram for more info!

Subject: Blood Drive next week added more time slots!

Pomona's first blood drive of the year is next Wednesday, October 8th! Because of a blood shortage in the area, we added more donation slots between 9am and 10am. Donate and save up to three lives (and get FREE SNACKS)!

To sign up, search for this drive on www.redcrossblood.org<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.redcrossblood.org%2F&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cb1affa4da68a4ddf587308d984357304%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637686187352960937%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=0mvvAu66LpFAIZAoVWJ8BGLx04YDzT0KCfVPPpZWVvQ%3D&reserved=0> or reach out to Claire Van Note.

\Terminate\
Subject: Join Team Bird Strike 47!

Advanced Animal Ecology students are participating in an international effort to reduce window strikes, the second highest cause of death of North American birds.

If you see a bird who has hit a window, please let us know which building and which side of the building. If you can, take a photo of the bird and email BirdStrike@pomona.edu<mailto:BirdStrike@pomona.edu>. If the bird is still alive, please also call 909-607-9794 and leave a detailed message about where the bird is so we can coordinate rescue.
\Terminate\
Subject: Want to become smarter in just 5+ minutes?

Subscribe to Morning Brew, an online, daily newsletter that makes reading the news enjoyable and fun! In this day and age, keeping up with the news is everything. Stop reading the dense, mundane news and business articles and sign up for Morning Brew today to stay informed and entertained... FOR FREE.

Subject: The 24/7 hotline run by the Campus Advocates is open!

Our 24/7 hotline for survivors of sexual assault is now open. Call 909-626-4357 and ask to speak with an advocate from Pomona College, who provide confidential support to survivors and anyone trying to help support a survivor. For more resources and information about the Campus Advocates, check out our Instagram page @campus_advocates47.

Subject: College Advising Opportunity at the 5Cs -- Open to All!

Matriculate is a non-profit that supports high-achieving, low-income high school students with college application process. Undergraduate Advising Fellows are paired with 1-4 students to serve as valuable mentors and guides. All advising is done virtually and Matriculate provides the training and support needed to support students and learn about college access.

We are currently recruiting students to serve as Advising Fellows for 2021-2022. Get started here: https://matriculate.smapply.io/<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmatriculate.smapply.io%2F&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cb1affa4da68a4ddf587308d984357304%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637686187352990804%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=C0b%2FzHxAI4djaq0R8mWRHSgZXU1BKb2bKtrP3llrzNA%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Matriculate Advising Fellow Applications are open - apply by 10/17!
Matriculate is a college access non-profit that supports high-achieving, low/moderate-income high school students to apply and enroll in a best-fit college by pairing students with Advising Fellows, who serve as mentors through the college application process. Matriculate provides the training and support needed to support students virtually and learn about college access. We are currently recruiting students to serve as Advising Fellows at Pomona. Apply at matriculate.smapply.io<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fmatriculate.smapply.io%2F&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cb1affa4da68a4ddf587308d984357304%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637686187353030629%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=EG4Rf5kjgGqVytqEICxhndQo3mgkmivQENE8N8uIk8k%3D&reserved=0> by 10/17!

Subject: Sagehens Abroad: Student Stories From Around the World (Study Abroad Podcast) Episode 4

Vienna and Ryan have a lively conversation about learning and communicating in a new language, living in a host family, and the Danish tradition of hygge.

Subject: Lunch Club - Lunch Club's First Matches Come Out Tomorrow

1. Sign up here: https://linktr.ee/lunchclub47
2. Choose Tues and/or Thurs
3. I send an email to you with your buddy's contact info
4. You choose the dining hall and time

Subject: 5C DANCE COMPANY AUDITION SUNDAY (9/26) - Come dance with us!

5C Dance Company is the ONLY 5C dance org that performs at CMS and PP football and basketball games, and we produce FREE, student-run semiannual showcases to highlight the talents of our individual dancers! Most dancers have a background in ballet or jazz dance; we perform a variety of styles, including ballet, heels, tap, hip-hop, and modern.

RSVP on Engage to sign up for our auditions this SUNDAY at Roberts Pavilion Studio A. Dancers of all styles and specialties are welcome to audition!

Subject: 5C Swim Club - Interest in Joining?

Want to swim with a group? Make your swims more fun and productive, or get some technique, stoke help from a coach. Want to get faster or learn how to do butterfly? Help start and join a 5C swim club!
This will be low stress and a great place for recreational/fitness swimmers who want to learn and former high school/college swimmers who want to keep at it. Please express your interest by contacting Al McKown amckown@pitzer.edu<mailto:amckown@pitzer.edu> for more information.

Subject: Claremont Business Group is recruiting for the fall!

Claremont Business Group is a 5C organization founded to apply our liberal arts education to business and professional development. With three initiatives - Impact, Consulting, and Voice - we provide mentorship and experiential learning opportunities for the Claremont Colleges.

To learn more about applying, join us at one of our info sessions!

Info Session #1: September 22nd 5PM, Lincoln 2114
Info Session #2: September 23rd 5PM, Lincoln 2114

Apply by September 26th: shorturl.at/hqtNO

PLUCKED ON BACH with Professor Joti Rockwell

Join us this Saturday, September 25 at 8pm in Bridges Hall of Music for this exciting free concert! Professor Rockwell presents an all-Bach program featuring solo sonatas and a suite originally written for violin and cello on American plucked-string instruments.

Link to September concert information: https://www.pomona.edu/academics/departments/music/concert-calendar/september

Subject: Join the 5C Public Health Club!
Interested in public or global health? Claremont Students for Public Health (CSPH) is a 5C club that aims to increase campus knowledge around public health issues, to guide students in seeking opportunities on/off campus, and connect with local orgs in the community. Subject: 5C DANCE COMPANY AUDITIONS NEXT SUNDAY (9/26) - RSVP on Engage to Sign Up!
5C Dance Company is the ONLY on-campus dance organization that performs at CMS and PP football and basketball games, and we produce FREE, student-run semiannual showcases to highlight the talents of our individual dancers! Most of our dancers have a background in ballet or jazz dance; for our student choreographed shows, we perform a variety of styles including ballet, heels, tap, hip-hop, and modern.
RSVP on ENGAGE for auditions coming up on Sunday 9/26 in Roberts Pavilion. See you there!

Subject: Ask the Congresswoman: A Conversation with U.
This Thursday, September 16, the Politics Department will be hosting the United States Representative for Nevada's 3rd Congressional District, Susie Lee. Representative Lee will discuss education policy, water policy, climate change, and nuclear energy, as well as her swing district. The event will also include a Q&A.
We will be hosting Representative Lee at the Carnegie Outdoor Classroom from 6 PM-7PM. We hope to see you there!

Subject: The Humanities Studio presents: Applying to Graduate School in the Humanities (A Panel Discussion)
Tues, Sept 14 | 4:30pm | Ena Thompson Room (Crookshank)
Pomona students are invited to a roundtable with UCLA grad advisors to learn about making the decision to go to grad school; selecting the right school; the importance of contacting potential advisors; crafting a personal statement, statement of purpose, and/or a diversity statement; selecting and polishing a writing sample; approaching letter writers; and funding your grad education. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series. Join us!
\Terminate\
Subject: Pomona College Department of Music: PLUCKED ON BACH with Professor Joti Rockwell
Join us on Saturday, September 25 at 8pm in Bridges Hall of Music for this exciting free concert! Professor Rockwell presents an all-Bach program featuring solo sonatas and a suite originally written for violin and cello on American plucked-string instruments.
Link to September concert information: https://www.pomona.edu/academics/departments/music/concert-calendar/september

Subject: Sign up for Pomona's first blood drive of the year!
Did you know that one blood donation can save up to three lives? Or that someone in the United States needs blood or platelets every two seconds? Come donate blood at Pomona's first blood drive of the year hosted with the Red Cross! Become a lifesaver (and eat free snacks afterwards).
Sign up at www.redcrossblood.org<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.redcrossblood.org%2F&data=04%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cecc7ed5870db4064cf7108d973b15028%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C637668027663210846%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=sGME0wfXJSdaOxdotMNLFJGhfpWuiMAOsY8DBNFC1aI%3D&reserved=0> with sponsor code "pomcol."
Open to all 7C students. Reach out to Claire with any questions.

Subject: Interested in consulting?
The Graphite Group is a student-run consulting group based out of the Claremont Colleges. We partner with businesses and nonprofits across the Inland Empire region to help local entrepreneurs achieve their strategic goals. In addition to client work, GG consultants develop as professionals through our group's skill-building workshops, mentorship programs with industry-professionals, and social events. Subject: Open Fora with the 3 CIO Finalists

On September 9-13, the three finalists for the position of Pomona College Chief Information Officer will be conducting campus visits. We have arranged large numbers of stakeholder meetings - both in person and virtual -- with members of our community.   In addition, we have arranged for open fora for interested faculty, staff and students to have an opportunity to meet each candidate.
The student open fora will be moderated zoom meetings held on:
Thursday, September 09, 4:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m.

Meeting ID: 817 7862 3680
Friday, September 10, 4:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m.

Meeting ID: 838 1159 5075
Monday, September 13, 4:00 p.m. - 5:00 p.m.

Meeting ID: 895 6567 3690
Please save the dates/times on your calendars.  A link will be sent each morning with background information about each candidate.
As you learn of each of our candidates, we ask that you please support them by ensuring the highest level of confidentiality and discretion by not sharing any information outside of the Pomona Community.
Thank you in advance for your participation, your input during this process is immensely valued.

Maria Watson, VP for Advancement; Chair, CIO Search Committee (on behalf of the full search committee)

Subject: Virtual Gallery Talk with Professor Heather Williams and Madeleine Mount-Cors '23
Tues., Sept. 14th, 11:15-11:50am student curator Madeleine Mount-Cors '23 and Professor Heather Williams will give a gallery talk on Zoom on select themes of "CrossBorder Photography: Images from the US and Mexico from the Permanent Collection," including portrayals of labor and militarization. This 20-minute informal, yet focused talk plus a Q&A session will be streamed live from the Benton. Please register at https://pomonacollege.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZEvcuqqpj4rEtIrzfjfsGormeaawJr57kdR.
Justine Bae Bias , Staff

Subject: Participate in paid social science research at the Experimental Lab!
We are recruiting potential participants for social science studies at the Pomona College Experimental Lab. Please follow the link to enter your name and details to sign up (signing up now simply means you will be contacted to participate in future experiments, and you can at that time decide if you want to or not; no commitment is made now). Participation in future experiments is compensated. Thanks so much, everyone!

Claremont Astronomical Society is a 5C amateur astronomy club educating the community through special events such as open observing nights at Brackett Observatory, Planetarium shows at the Pomona Planetarium, trips to Griffith Observatory, and camping adventures to see the stars. We are looking (for tons) of new leaders! Everyone is welcome to apply and no experience is necessary. Applications are accepted on a rolling basis. 10-week virtual support group for 7C students who have experienced dating or domestic violence, whether recently or long ago. This EmPOWER Center group is facilitated by therapists from House of Ruth and is open to students of all gender identities.
Wednesdays from 4:30 - 6 PM PST

Subject: The EmPOWER Center - Weekly Support Group for Survivors of Sexual Assault
This 10-week virtual group is designed for students who have experienced sexual assault/abuse, whether recently or long ago. The group is facilitated by Evelin Setaghian, Psy.D., the EmPOWER Center's Project Sister Family Services therapist. Open to 7C students of all gender identities.


Call 909.607.0690 to sign up by Sept. 16th.
*We are open to changing the day/time the group meets if interested students prefer a different day/time.

Subject: Benton Museum of Art at Pomona College: Botanical Illustrations Workshop at the Benton on 4/4/24

Inspired by Stitch Field: Alice-Marie Archer's Agritextiles, join artist Lilly Marinelli to discover the art of botanical illustrations. Bring plants to life on paper during this 2-hour hands-on workshop. Designed for all skill levels, we will cover methods of observation as well as pencil and pen techniques. The practice of botanical illustration is part scientific, part meditative, and all creative. Register to attend https://pomona.formstack.com/forms/botanical_illustrations_benton<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fpomona.formstack.com%2Fforms%2Fbotanical_illustrations_benton&data=05%7C02%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C59aface2f6ac4e2b818208dc49c8d1a0%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638466375551210410%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C60000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=7LMydxsJKbAkKX0hNF%2B5PWkMmOHVK36Jk5WwvUqECcU%3D&reserved=0>.

Subject: Politics Department Guest Speaker Talks: Rev.

Subject: Teal Dot Basics - Pomona

Teal Dot is a crucial 7C program designed to reduce sexual assault, dating/domestic violence, and stalking on campus. Preventing violence on campus takes a community effort and we are all stakeholders in this issue. The training will equip students to recognize potentially dangerous situations and safely intervene to safely intervene to prevent violence. The training is interactive, informative, engaging, and impactful.

RSVP on Engage (bit.ly/tealdotPOM) for the Pomona session on 03/22 at 10am!

They've exhibited art in places such as the 10th Central American Biennial, International Film Festival of El Salvador, Queens Museum, The Museum of Art El Salvador, and a solo exhibit at The Museum of Contemporary Art, Costa Rica.
Event will be held in the Ena Thompson Room Crookshank 108
\Terminate\

Subject: Philosophy - Friendship: A Virtue? - a talk by Allison Murphy, Carleton College
Aristotle claims that "friendship is either
a certain virtue or involves virtue"
(Nicomachean Ethics VIII.1), without ever
explicitly resolving the matter. I will argue
that friendship is not a virtue for
Aristotle. Instead, the shared life of
friendship is equivalent to the flourishing
(happiness) that is the focus of the rest of
the Ethics, though now it is flourishing
\Terminate\
Subject: Benton Museum of Art at Pomona College - Artist-led Workshop on Botanical Illustrations
Inspired by Stitch Field: Alice-Marie Archer's Agritextiles, join artist Lilly Marinelli to discover the art of botanical illustrations. Bring plants to life on paper during this 2-hour hands-on workshop. Designed for all skill levels, we will cover methods of observation as well as pencil and pen techniques. The practice of botanical illustration is part scientific, part meditative, and all creative.
Registration required https://pomona.formstack.com/forms/. Priority seating for 5C students.
\Terminate\

Subject: KSPC 88.

Join KSPC for a screening of "35,000 Watts: The Story of College Radio," which charts the wild journey of visionaries and rebels on college campuses across America who changed the course of music history and made an indelible imprint on our culture. Subject: Politics Department - Guest Speaker: Rev.
Please join us on March 26th from 12-1 pm for a Pizza and Politics with Reverend Don Abram. In this talk, Don will share his journey from a politics major at Pomona College to becoming a public theologian advocating for LGBTQ+ communities.
Additionally, Abram will be speaking from 7-9 pm in the Rose Hills Theater for the Lorn Foster lecture. This lecture will focus on Black Queer Spirituality as a Sacred Epistemology.

Subject: Psychology Research Study Participation for Credit and/or Raffle Entry

Participate in my online senior thesis study on young adults' experiences of spending time alone! Earn 0.5 research participation credits if eligible and be entered into a raffle to receive one of three $40 VISA gift cards. And, spend some time reflecting on the alone-time in your life! The survey only takes about 20 minutes.

If you would like to participate, click the link below to access the survey. https://pitzer.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_8jlGJrL1uY3YwNE<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fpitzer.co1.qualtrics.com%2Fjfe%2Fform%2FSV_8jlGJrL1uY3YwNE&data=05%7C02%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C59aface2f6ac4e2b818208dc49c8d1a0%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638466375551154621%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C60000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=JTWJO0gH88T0zz7WBAFc%2Fqjg6khSGTVsLp9kP6t%2BZtM%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Seeking participants for thesis experiment on smell perception.

Subject: Benton Museum of Art at Pomona College: Botanical Illustrations Workshop at the Benton on 4/4/24

Inspired by Stitch Field: Alice-Marie Archer's Agritextiles, join artist Lilly Marinelli to discover the art of botanical illustrations. Bring plants to life on paper during this 2-hour hands-on workshop. Designed for all skill levels, we will cover methods of observation as well as pencil and pen techniques. The practice of botanical illustration is part scientific, part meditative, and all creative. Register to attend https://pomona.formstack.com/forms/botanical_illustrations_benton<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fpomona.formstack.com%2Fforms%2Fbotanical_illustrations_benton&data=05%7C02%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C59aface2f6ac4e2b818208dc49c8d1a0%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638466375551210410%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C60000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=7LMydxsJKbAkKX0hNF%2B5PWkMmOHVK36Jk5WwvUqECcU%3D&reserved=0>.

Subject: ‚Äú35,000 Watts: The Story of College Radio‚Äù Documentary Screening and Fundraiser

Join KSPC for a screening of "35,000 Watts: The Story of College Radio," which charts the wild journey of visionaries and rebels on college campuses across America who changed the course of music history and made an indelible imprint on our culture. Subject: Politics Department Guest Speaker Talks: Rev.

Please join us on March 26th from 12-1 pm for a Pizza and Politics with Reverend Don Abram. In this talk, Don will share his journey from a politics major at Pomona College to becoming a public theologian advocating for LGBTQ+ communities.

\Terminate\
Subject: Teal Dot Basics - Pomona

Teal Dot is a crucial 7C program designed to reduce sexual assault, dating/domestic violence, and stalking on campus. Preventing violence on campus takes a community effort and we are all stakeholders in this issue. The training will equip students to recognize potentially dangerous situations and safely intervene to safely intervene to prevent violence. The training is interactive, informative, engaging, and impactful.

RSVP on Engage (bit.ly/tealdotPOM) for the Pomona session on 03/22 at 10am!

Subject: Recruiting participants for senior thesis!

Hello! I am a senior at Pomona majoring in Psychology, and I am currently recruiting participants for my senior thesis studying culture, friendship, and stress. It is a 30-minute in-person study, and you will be compensated with a $10 Amazon gift card for your time. Subject: KSPC 88.
We will be screening 35,000 Watts: The Story of College Radio on March 28 at 7 PM at Rose Hills Theatre. This feature documentary discusses the history of college radio and its impact on music and culture, as told by the students who were on the air and the bands they made famous. The documentary features members of Devo, Bratmobile, Pixies, KSPC staff, and more. There will be a Q and A afterwards with people featured in the documentary, including KSPC's director Erica Tyron.

Subject: Pomona Gender and Women's Studies - The Making of the American Calorie and Metabolic Metrics of Empire: A Chau Mellon Candidate Talk by Dr.
Join us for a talk with Chau Mellon candidate Dr. Athia Choudhury, to be held in the GWS house, 740 N. College Ave. (at 8th St.), on Wednesday, March 6, 2024 from 4:15-6:00pm. Her talk uncovers the racial life of the American calorie, tracking practices of energy management and bodily discipline from colonial military outposts, nineteenth-century domestic manuals, dietetic discourses in the Philippines, and Native American Boarding Schools.

Subject: English Department Event 2/29 Toby Altman Poetry Reading 2/29

Please join the English Department for a reading by early career poet and scholar of Renaissance literature, Toby Altman, from his new book Discipline Park in the Ena Thompson Room 108 of Crookshank on Thursday 2/29 at 4:30.  His book manuscript, entitled Diachronic Renaissance: Periodization, Poetics, and The Shock of the Old, traces "subterranean connections between Renaissance and avant-garde poetics."  Think of it as an intellectual genealogy for his own practices as a poet!

 "The Suburban Crisis: White America and the War on Drugs"

Join Matthew Lassiter, professor of history at the University of Michigan, for a casual discussion about the politics of drug policy as it has differed between predominantly white suburban communities and predominantly minority urban communities. Subject: Sustainability Office - Sustainable fashion show at the Benton

Join us on February 29th from 7-9 pm at the Benton Museum of Art for the Freeroom's annual sustainable fashion show. This year's theme is "Conscious couture: stories of slow fashion," which aims to rejuvenate the runway by showcasing student designs made entirely from secondhand material, ranging from Free Room-sourced fabric to thrift store beads. We hope you join us for a spectacular evening at the Benton where walking art and the hopeful future of fashion will be on display!

Subject: The Sage Fellows Program is open for business!
Sage Fellows  offers individual academic coaches, drop-in office hours (no appointment required) &  workshops to help students achieve academic success. They can assist students with time management; organization; study habits & strategies; reading & note-taking skills; motivation & procrastination; stress management & wellness strategies; and more fully accessing campus resources.
Book an appointment or see drop in sessions : https://pomona.mywconline.com

Subject: KSPC 88.
Join us for a screening and Q&A with director Daniel Weintraub
Thursday, February 29th at 6pm in Rose Hills Theatre
"Deep Listening: The Story of Pauline Oliveros" tells the story of the iconic composer, performer, teacher, philosopher, technological innovator and humanitarian, Pauline Oliveros. She was one of the world's original electronic musicians, one of the only females amongst notable post-war American composers, a master accordion player, a teacher and mentor to musicians.
\Terminate\
Subject: Media Studies - Americonned Screening and Panel
Please join us for a screening of Americonned, followed by a panel with the director, Sean Claffey, and president of the Amazon Labor Union, Chris Smalls.
Americonned is film about income inequality in the US and its tragic destabilizing effects to Americans. The documentary depicts activists like Chris Smalls who leads a movement to unionize Amazon workers for the first time, after the corporation fired Smalls for speaking up for workers' rights.
February 28th @ 6:30pm in Rose Hills Theater
\Terminate\
Subject: English Department - Toby Altman: Poetry Reading
Please join us for a poetry reading by author and poet, Toby Altman. Altman is the author of Jewel Box (Essay Press, 2025), Discipline Park (Wendy's Subway, 2023), and Arcadia, Indiana (Plays Inverse, 2017). His criticism has been widely published, including articles and essays in Contemporary Literature, English Literary History, The Georgia Review, and Jack. Refreshments will be served.
February 29th @ 4:30pm in Ena Thompson Crookshank 108
\Terminate\

Subject: Sustainability Office - Sustainable fashion show at the Benton
Join us on February 29th from 7-9 pm at the Benton Museum of Art for the Freeroom's annual sustainable fashion show. This year's theme is "Conscious couture: stories of slow fashion," which aims to rejuvenate the runway by showcasing student designs made entirely from secondhand material, ranging from Free Room-sourced fabric to thrift store beads. We hope you join us for a spectacular evening at the Benton where walking art and the hopeful future of fashion will be on display!

Subject: CSPH and Keck Prehealth Health System Simulation Competition

Join us February 28th 6-7:30 pm in Burns Lecture Hall for a night of food and prizes as you work in a team to solve scenarios based on real-life shortcomings in the US healthcare system! Modeled from the national CLARION Competition, students are called to critically look at healthcare infrastructure, patient care, and social services, to determine what can be done to better our society and medicine. Especially valuable for pre-health students! RSVP: http://tinyurl.com/mv6rsf5n<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fmv6rsf5n&data=05%7C02%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C1b089d656863417a4e2e08dc33ce42ef%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638442208194269342%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=d%2Fi7O0%2Bp9vaPS1My6U7q0eYK02Ue9Aj%2FElPfwp7ZzlM%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: 5C UNRWA Fundraiser for Gaza

Right now, HALF A MILLION refugees in Gaza are facing FAMINE-level starvation. And four out of five of the hungriest people anywhere in the world are in Gaza per the UN.

Join 7C MSA, JVP, SWANA, and SJP in helping UNRWA provide aid to GAZAN Refugees through our 5C Fundraiser campaign. Just $40 provides a whole Palestine refugee family with lifesaving drinking water and food.

Read more & donate here - https://gofund.me/763fb092

Your donation saves Gazan lives.

Subject: The Sage Fellows Program is open for business!

Sage Fellows  offers individual academic coaches, drop-in office hours (no appointment required) &  workshops to help students achieve academic success. They can assist students with time management; organization; study habits & strategies; reading & note-taking skills; motivation & procrastination; stress management & wellness strategies; and more fully accessing campus resources.

Subject: Classics Department - Hen Talks: Special Mideast Edition

Ken Wolf (LAMS), Chris Chinn (Classics), and Penny Sinanoglou (History) at 4:15 on Tuesday, February 13, in Estella 1051 for the first of the HenTalks of the spring semester. This episode will be a special one featuring three distinct historical slices of the Holy Land-one ancient, one medieval, and one modern-designed to broaden the conversation about this troubled part of the world. Each presenter will have only 15 minutes to work with. When we are done, expect a robust Q&A period.

Subject: Indigenous Tattooing in Okinawa - A Workshop Hosted by the Asian American Resource Center (AARC) x Pacific Islander Empowerment (PIE)

Join us at the AARC (SCC Room 240) on Friday, February 16th from 4:30pm-6:00pm for "Indigenous Tattooing in Okinawa." This workshop, featuring Ava Chir≈´ Kvapil, will cover a brief history of hajichi, its symbology and various styles across the Ry≈´ky≈´ Kingdom, and how it is being practiced today. Participants will be able to use temporary tattoo markers to make their own ""hajichi-inspired"" hand tattoos. Snacks and drinks will be provided :]
\Terminate\
Subject: AAMP x BSU x LXA - POC BBQ Cookout Tomorrow!

Come join us on Friday, Feb. 16 at 5pm for a POC BBQ Cookout hosted by AAMP, BSU, and LXA! There will be Soul Food, Korean BBQ, Pupusas, and more. The event will be in the South Campus Grills between Harwood/Lyon and Mudd. Hope to see you there!
\Terminate\
Subject: English Department ‚ÄúClothed in our Framed Attire" with Kimberly Johnson  - February 21st Crookshank 108 4:30pm

2/21/24 Ena Thompson 108 4:30pm

Join us for a talk from poet and literary critic Kimberly Johnson. In her volume Salve Deus Rex Judaeorum, Aemilia Lanyer uses metaphors from the fabric arts and stitches together her spiritual contemplations with terminology from sempstressry, spinning a thread between Christ's incarnation and the domestic sphere. This talk will show how Lanyer uses language from what is conventionally dismissed as mere women's work to claim Christ under the authority of women.
\Terminate\

Subject: Claremont Students for Public Health - PUBLIC HEALTH FACULTY MIXER

Join us on February 28th from 6-7:30 pm for a night of food, problem-solving, and prizes as you work in a team to solve scenarios based on real-life shortcomings in the US healthcare system! Modeled from the national CLARION Competition,  students are called to critically look at healthcare infrastructure, patient care, social services, and more to determine where patients failed and what can we do to better our society and medicine. Especially valuable for pre-health students! Location TBA.

Elizabeth Wydra '98, President, Constitutional Accountability Center will discuss how reproductive autonomy is essential to equal citizenship, and how the Supreme Court's reversal of Roe v. Wade got the Constitution wrong. She will also share her experiences as a woman leader of a constitutional law organization.

Subject: Asian American Resource Center - Indigenous Tattooing in Okinawa - A Workshop Hosted by the Asian American Resource Center (AARC) x Pacific Islander Empowerment (PIE)
Join us at the AARC (SCC Room 240) on Friday, February 16th from 4:30pm-6:00pm for "Indigenous Tattooing in Okinawa." This workshop, featuring Ava Chir≈´ Kvapil, will cover a brief history of hajichi, its symbology and various styles across the Ry≈´ky≈´ Kingdom, and how it is being practiced today. Participants will be able to use temporary tattoo markers to make their own "hajichi-inspired" hand tattoos. Snacks and drinks will be provided :D

Subject: Pomona Anthro Dept.

The Pomona Anthropology Department is looking for student photographs, film stills, or other visual art created in the process of an anthropology project. You don't need to be an anthro major--we want to show the amazing work that students in anthropology have done! If selected, your work will be framed on Hahn's walls as part of the department's first-ever ethnographic gallery. Submissions close Mar. 1.

Subject: Resiliency In The Flesh: Building Trans Power During Adversity

Join us for a lunchtime lecture on February 2nd from 12:15-1:00 pm in Rose Hills Theater with Bamby Salcedo! Bamby will speak as part of the Power Series and Gender and Health Series. She has brought more visibility to the intersectional identities and stories of LGBTQ+, Latinx, youth, migrant, and incarcerated identities. "Resiliency In The Flesh" will offer lessons on strength and power amidst adversity in the transgender community and beyond!

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents: Tish Harrison Warren on the Texture of Joy

TODAY! Thurs, Feb 1 | 7 p.m. | Rose Hills Theatre

Join the Humanities Studio as we welcome Anglican priest, author, and New York Times contributor Tish Harrison Warren for a conversation about "The Texture of Joy." Harrison will explore what joy is (and isn't), what poets and thinkers have told us about the meaning of joy, and the relationship between grief, suffering and joy. It's the fourth event in our 2023-2024 Joy Speakers Series.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Toolkit Session: Opinion Writing Workshop with New York Times Editor Teresa Tritch

Wed, Feb 1 / 1-4pm / SCC 201 (Hart Room)

The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Register & learn more at bit.ly/opedwithtritch

Subject: Do you want locally-sourced produce? Buy a CSA Share :)
Ever wish for fresh fruits and veggies...introducing your local alternative- Claremont Market Shares (CSA)! We are a Pitzer-based student-run market share community organization that works with local farms to bring fresh produce to the Claremont community. We distribute shares every Thursday, starting in February so sign up now to guarantee your spot :) If you are interested in purchasing a share or volunteering for CSA, sign up here: https://forms.gle/qzWcRQjuHJvzweFP9<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FqzWcRQjuHJvzweFP9&data=05%7C02%7CAll_Students%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cd28c8577b9aa427d14ca08dc20f743b4%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638421493570454972%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=ZOoBbH8eYIayXRyamGPOwnQUtIKUwILStzE6HbMS%2BqE%3D&reserved=0>.

And no experience is needed! All people are welcome!

If you are interested in Designing, Stage Managing, or Assistant Directing email edab2020@mymail.pomona.edu<mailto:edab2020@mymail.pomona.edu>
\Terminate\
Subject: Do you want locally-sourced produce? Buy a CSA Share :)
Ever wish for fresh fruits and veggies...introducing your local alternative- Claremont Market Shares (CSA)! We are a Pitzer-based student-run market share community organization that works with local farms to bring fresh produce to the Claremont community. We distribute shares every Thursday, starting in February so sign up now to guarantee your spot :)  If you are interested in purchasing a share or volunteering for CSA, sign up here: https://forms.gle/qzWcRQjuHJvzweFP9<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FqzWcRQjuHJvzweFP9&data=05%7C02%7CAll_Students%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Ccbfb47e71eb447e5bea508dc1dcb604f%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638418006540655011%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=n3i6AxqqEJPPOjL5HtT%2BbWKMfHtsqFBKpfi7%2FPgYJQU%3D&reserved=0>.

Subject: Tish Harrison Warren on the Texture of Joy
Thurs, Feb 1  |  7 p.m.  |  Rose Hills Theatre
Join the Humanities Studio as we welcome Anglican priest, author, and New York Times contributor Tish Harrison Warren for a conversation about ""The Texture of Joy."" Harrison will explore what joy is (and isn't), what poets and thinkers have told us about the meaning of joy, and the relationship between grief, suffering and joy. It's the fourth event in our 2023-2024 Joy Speakers Series.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Toolkit Session: Opinion Writing Workshop with Teresa Tritch
Wed, Feb 1 / 1-4pm / SCC 201 (Hart Room)
The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Register & learn more at bit.ly/opedwithtritch
\Terminate\
Subject: The Three Mothers | How the Mothers of MLK Jr, Malcom X, & James Baldwin shaped a Nation
January 30, 2024 | 4p.m. | Benson Auditorium Pitzer College
Have you ever thought about the contribution of mothers in shaping our nation in the face of patriarchy?
Did your K-12 history books give a nuanced understanding of the Civil Rights Movement?
Join us as we unpack these questions and more in the first installment of the Presidential dialogues Initiative. Reception immediately following.
Division of Student Affairs Pitzer , Staff

Subject: Passionate about addressing food insecurity in the community and reducing food waste?
The mission of the Food Recovery Network is to deliver food leftovers from the on-campus dining halls to local community partners. Volunteers operate in teams of two, one driver and one handler. No driver's license is needed to be a handler.
If interested please complete this form.

Information session is January 30th 7-8 pm at the Draper Center (735 Dartmouth Avenue) for new volunteers, bring driver's license.

Subject: Health Bridges and the Pomona Student Union
Transgender Latina Activist Bamby Salcedo Coming to the 5Cs! Join us for a lunchtime lecture on February 2nd from 12:15-1:00 pm in Rose Hills Theater with Bamby Salcedo! Bamby will speak as part of the Power Series and Gender and Health Series. Bamby has brought more visibility to the intersectional identities and stories of LGBTQ+, Latinx, youth, migrant, and incarcerated identities. "Resiliency In The Flesh"" will offer lessons on strength and power amidst adversity in the transgender community and beyond.

Subject: Claremont Christian Fellowship Friday Fellowship

Smith Campus Center 201 (Hart Room). This Friday at 7pm. Claremont Christian Fellowship is diverse, inclusive, and queer affirming.

Subject: OLC Being There: Reflections on a Claremont Faculty-Student Study Tour to Palestine/Israel

In May 2023, the Institute for Global and Local Studies sponsored a study tour to Palestine/Israel that included students and faculty from both Pitzer and Claremont McKenna Colleges. In this lunch conversation, Professors Acu (Mathematics, PZ) and Ferguson (History, CMC) will share their reasons for participating in the tour, some key moments they experienced during the 10 days moving across varied landscapes and contexts, and reflections on the impact of "being there."

Subject: Health Bridges - Houselessness, Gender, and Health with Kate Pocock

Want to learn about how healthcare professionals provide gender-sensitive care to unhoused people? Come to the speaker event on Thursday, October 26, at 12:15 p.m. in Frank Blue Room!

Kate Pocock, an MHS, PA-C, and Instructor of Family Medicine working with USC Street Medicine, will discuss social determinants of health. See how her team provides medical care to gender-nonconforming folks and LGBTQ+ populations living on the street.

Subject: Visiting Assistant Professor of English stef torralba
Trans of Color Cinemas: Rare & New Short Films (Free Screening)
Starting at 7 PM Saturday Oct. 21 in Pomona Studio Art Hall 122, Visiting Assistant Professor of English stef torralba will host a screening of rare and new short films that tell the stories of trans people of color. These shorts have never been widely released and cannot be publicly accessed. Screenings will be followed by snacks and an in-person conversation with one of the writer-directors: emerging filmmaker Emory Chao Johnson. Free and open to the 5C's community. Free snacks!

Subject: Open Academy Saturday Salon: Art and Morality

Subject: Project Horsehoe Farm Community Health Fellowship- Info Session
4:15-5:00pm | Sep. 26 | Estella 2113
Project Horseshoe Farm offers a competitive national fellowship focused on developing tomorrow's community health leaders. Subject: Audition for THE ALIENS this Friday 9/08 and Saturday 9/09!
The Green Room Student Theater is producing The Aliens by Annie Baker, directed by Sophie David and Jo Keyser! The Aliens tells the story of two angry young men behind a Vermont coffee shop who talk music and Bukowski until a lonely high school student arrives and they decide to teach him everything they know. We are open to all levels of experience!
Auditions are Friday 9/08 from 5-8pm and Saturday 9/09 from 1-6pm. SIGN UP TO AUDITION: bit.ly/aliens5c
Sophie David and Jo Keyser, Students

Subject: Pomona Ventures - FALL 2023 APPLICATIONS OPEN
Pomona Ventures is a start-up ecosystem where students learn from founders, support founders, and find their co-founders. We also host Sparkathon, a design thinking case competition, and SageTank, a pitch competition for 5C student founders. If you are interested in startups, product design, VC, or tech, PV is the place for you. All majors and backgrounds are welcome!

Subject: Complete a library research survey and earn a $10 Amazon gift card
Do you want to learn effective search skills?

As a librarian with The Claremont Colleges Library, I'm exploring the search habits of first-year undergraduate students enrolled in STEM. I'm offering a $10 Amazon gift card to the first 50 students who fully complete my online research survey, Search Like a Scholar. The survey takes about 20-30 mins to complete and is geared toward first-year STEM students who have not met with a subject librarian. Visit: https://7clib.cc/3YlbRvb<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2F7clib.cc%2F3YlbRvb&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cdf6ed843b69f4807d9e308dbafcaaa0c%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638297057221549102%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=PHZ8z9bdQImKAAW4ZVZ3Rbacoq91Sl%2B40oktIipaczU%3D&reserved=0>

The Aliens tells the story of two angry young men behind a Vermont coffee shop who talk music and Bukowski until a lonely high school student arrives and they decide to teach him everything they know. We are open to all levels of experience!
Auditions are Friday 9/08 from 5-8pm and Saturday 9/09 from 1-6pm. SIGN UP TO AUDITION: bit.ly/aliens5c
Sophie  David and Jo Keyser, Students
\Terminate\

Subject: Oldenborg OLC~ Conversation Courses: A Roundtable with the Language Residents

5/2 ~12:15pm, Oldenborg Dining Hall
Each semester, the Language Residents (LRs) and their students think of creative, engaging projects that get them involved in the common goal of using the target language as a tool, which both facilitates teamwork on a project and produces content for the project. Join us in listening to the LRs talk about their projects in their Intermediate and/or Advanced classes in Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Russian, and Spanish

Subject: Project Sunshine - Project Sunshine Fundraiser: 50/50 Raffle!

Project Sunshine is a nonprofit supporting pediatric patients by harnessing the healing power of play.

The 50/50 raffle is one of our most recent fundraisers. The winning raffle ticket will win 50% of the revenue generated from ticket sales, and the other 50% of the proceeds will be used to create more care packages for kids. You can contribute to our mission by buying a raffle ticket for $3,  completing the Google form(tinyurl.com/ypu7w4ut), and Venmo the cost to @mayracoruh.
\Terminate\
Subject: 5/2 ~12:15pm, Oldenborg Dining Hall

Each semester, the Language Residents (LRs) and their students think of creative, engaging projects that get them involved in the common goal of using the target language as a tool which both facilitates teamwork on a project and produces content for the project. Join us in listening to the LRs talk about their projects in their Intermediate and/or Advanced classes in Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Russian, and Spanish

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents - LeiLani Nishime & Kim D.
Thurs, April 27 / 4:30pm / Estella 1051
Join the Humanities Studio in welcoming LeiLani Nishime and Kim Hester Williams, co-editors of the book "Racial Ecologies", to speak with us about environmental degradation and new world making in the final talk of our Human/Nature Speakers Series. Nishime and Williams will draw from the work of POC and Indigenous activists to explore how to incorporate our histories, introduce alternative worldviews, and create spaces to imagine new futures.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library - New Exhibit at the Asian Library
Through September 1st, visit the Asian Library at The Claremont Colleges Library to explore the exhibition on "War & Gender in East Asia During WWII: Historical Reality & Contemporary Recollection", which is based on the senior thesis of a Scripps College student. The exhibit features first-hand recollections of surviving "comfort women" and a life-size gynecological examination table, which was recreated using archival documents, museum objects and oral history interviews. 7clib.cc/War-Gender
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Feminist Encounters with Historical Trauma Panel Discussion
Join us on May 1st at 4:15 PM in the Founders Room for a panel discussion on "Feminist Encounters with Historical Trauma: Conversations Across Historical Times and Geographical Space". Three feminist scholars will discuss the emotional burden of witnessing historical trauma and sexual violence, as well as touch on their experiences dealing with these sensitive topics through productive ways of expression like exhibition, artwork, pedagogy and writing. More: 7clib.cc/FemEncounters

\Terminate\
Subject: Media Studies - Yuilya Lanina, 4/27 @ 4:15 PM, Ena Thompson Room, Crookshank Hall
Join the Pomona College Media Studies Department for this year's Pinkel Lecture. Assistant Professor of Practice at University of Texas, Austin and interdisciplinary artist Yuliya Lanina presents her lecture "Animating Silence: Trauma, War, and Hope." Through animation, installation, sculpture and performance, Lanina will address personal and collective issues of war, repression, violence, and trauma.
The Pinkel Lecture in Media Studies is in honor of Benjamin and Anne A. Pinkel.

Subject: Inclusive Claremont - Study in Solidarity with Claremont Tenants!
This Tuesday, April 25th at 6:30pm, the City Council is debating a permanent ordinance to address no-fault evictions and rent stabilization in Claremont, and we need to show support for bold action to protect tenants. Inclusive Claremont is going to be studying in solidarity with Claremont tenants at City Hall (225 W 2nd Street), so plan to bring your homework and show your support. Snacks and boba will be provided! Sign up: https://linktr.ee/inclusiveclaremont<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flinktr.ee%2Finclusiveclaremont&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Ccfaea9306ca04f94647608db44f21041%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638179578666046983%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=BErE0KCvIl9NYrDTEYrzC5Gp0kWxNJewLgwygf%2FlZJw%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Health Bridges  Inequalities in Health, Wealth, and Power with UCLA's Dr.
This Thursday (4/27) at 12:15 in Hahn 101, Dr. Naomi Zewde, a scholar of public policy who has been featured in numerous academic outlets as well as the New York Times and PBS Newshour, will be coming to discuss her work. She studies how public institutions can deliver medical care and economic security across the economic distribution and is currently researching private-insurance contracting in the Medicaid program.
Lunch will be provided. Please RSVP at tinyurl.com/ZewdeEvent.

Get FREE boba and learn from Pape Moussa Sonko, the artistic director of the national ballet of Senegal. Sonko will share how he has worked to share the diverse cultures of the peoples of Senegal with the world throughout his career as an internationally renowned artist. Additionally, he will help us explore tools of cultural representation and cross-cultural engagement.
When? Monday, April 24th, @7:00 PM

Subject: Fundraiser for Roof Repair of a Non-Profit South LA Medical Clinic

Universal Community Health Center is a nonprofit started by Pomona alumnus Dr. Edgar Chavez that has provided quality care to underserved populations in South LA. During recent storms, part of the ceiling in their newest clinic collapsed, causing significant damage. The cost of repair is high, and any donation will help the clinic return to providing critical healthcare to the community. Please donate to this GoFundMe to help!

Subject: Publish your work in the Claremont Journal of Law and Public Policy!
The Claremont Journal of Law and Public Policy is now accepting submissions for our Spring 2023 print publication. This is a great opportunity to have final research papers from your classes or other pieces you've been working on published. Submit papers (10-20 pages in length) within the field of law and public policy to info.5clpp@gmail.com by April 23 to be considered.

Subject: Class of 2026: Are you interested in the Robert Day Scholars Program?
The Robert Day BA Scholars program equips future leaders for success in a variety of careers. Members of the class of 2026 from all majors and 5Cs can apply! Upon acceptance, required coursework includes finance, accounting, and leadership. Personal and professional development activities and scholarship support are integral parts of this highly competitive program.
RSVP in Handshake for an info session!
Tuesday, 4/18 @ 4:30pm in Pickford Auditorium
Wednesday, 4/19 @ 12:15pm in Bauer Forum

Subject: Politics Department Pizza and Politics - Thursday April 20th
On Thursday, April 20th come to Carnegie 107 to enjoy pizza and meet Prof Ibrahim Yahaya Ibrahim, senior Sahel analyst with the International Crisis Group. His research relates to Islam and Politics, Political Contestations, and Violent Conflict in West Africa's Sahel region. This event is co-sponsored by the International Relations Department. Hope to see you there!

Subject: Ena Thompson Lecture Spring 2023, "Million Dollar Hoods: The Costs of Incarceration in Los Angeles"


Rose Hills Theatre, Smith Campus Center
Professor Kelly Lytle Hernandez is a professor of History, African American Studies, and Urban Planning at the University of California at Los Angeles and serves as the director of the Ralph J. Bunche Center for African American Studies at UCLA. Lytle Hernandez is one of the nation's leading experts on race, immigration, and mass incarceration.

Subject: Original Musical: It Just Takes Time
Come see the world premier of It Just Takes Time, written and directed by Annika Hoseth!

A college student, a restaurant owner, a shelter puppy, an engaged couple, and a kindergarten teacher don't have much in common until COVID19 forces them to figure out a new normal. They navigate loneliness, impatience, and loss while also learning to appreciate the "little wins."
Seats are FREE and first come - first served

Saturday, April 22 2PM & 8PM

Subject: Staff Council - This Is Your Brain On Food: Tues.

Harvard-trained psychiatrist/nutrition expert Dr. Uma Naidoo draws on cutting-edge research to explain the many ways in which food contributes to our mental health, and shows how a sound diet can help treat and prevent a wide range of psychological/cognitive health issues. RSVP to tiny.cc/dr_uma to attend the Live Zoom Watch Party at Edmunds Ballroom OR obtain the Zoom link to view on your own on Tues., Apr. 18 @12 noon. At the live event you will be able to sample some of Dr. Naidoo's recipes.

Subject: The Humanities Toolkit Session:Opinion Writing Workshop with Teresa Tritch

TOMORROW! Friday, April 14 / 1-4pm / Hahn 101

The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Learn more at bit.ly/opedwithtritch

Subject: KSPC x QRC - QUEER PROM

You are cordially invited to the greatest prom in all the land! Featuring live music from your favorite student artists, dancing, snacks, a photo spot, face painting, and extremely ‚ú® good ‚ú® vibes ‚ú® We're throwing it back to our MySpace days, so come in your best Y2K/early 2000s prom regalia.
ALL 7C STUDENTS ARE WELCOME
For more information email outreach@kspc.org

The Claremont Colleges Library Guided Exhibition Tour- Archiving Social Movements
Join us for a guided exhibition tour of Archiving Social Movements led by student curators and Visiting Assistant Professor Whitney DeVos (PO '08). The tour includes an overview of the curation process and exhibit themes, which include literature and social movements, radical spaces of The Claremont Colleges and visual culture as traces of struggle. After the tour, attendees are encouraged to ask questions and enjoy light refreshments.

Subject: Articulating and Enacting Black Disability Politics in the National Black Women's Health Project - Dr.

Drawn from the book Black Disability Politics (Duke UP Fall 2022), this talk discusses the history of the National Black Women's Health Project in the 1980s and 1990s arguing that the organization's Black feminist health activism used holistic, culturally-attuned and politicized approaches to health which should be considered an example of Black disability politics.

Argue Auditorium 1051, Estella Laboratory
\Terminate\

Subject: Speaker event: Organizing for Prison Industrial Complex Abolition !

Saturday, April 8 ! The Hive Studio 1 ! We are excited to announce that Saturday, April 8, the 5C Prison Abolition Collective will be joined by Amber-Rose Howard, Executive Director of the abolitionist policy organization CURB (curbprisonspending.org). Experiencing a felony conviction as a young adult propelled Amber-Rose into a lifetime commitment of organizing against the Prison Industrial Complex and building up the power of Black people and all others impacted by state violence and racial capitalism. We are excited to hear more!

Join us TODAY for Pomona College's 5th Annual Fresh Check Day!

A program of the Jordan Porco Foundation, this event is a mental health check-in with music, interactive booths, games and activities, and great prizes! Connect with campus resources such as MCAPS, DOS, QRC, ARS, CARES/TIX, and many more!

Presented by the Pomona College Wellness Taskforce as part of the 47 Days of Wellness initiative.

Time: 12:00 - 2:00 PM
\Terminate\
Subject: Mgrublian Center for Human Rights - Kwibuka, Rwandan Genocide Walk to Remember

Join the Rwandan Student Community at the Claremont Colleges for a Walk to Remember this Friday, April 7th.

The walk is the 29th commemoration of the 1994 genocide perpetrated against the Tutsi population in Rwanda.

Participants should meet at 5pm at Walker Beach, Pomona College, to walk together to Harvey Mudd for a vigil.

Following the walk and vigil there will be a screening of the documentary, The 600: The Soldiers' Story.

Dinner (Cane's) will be provided, all are welcome!
\Terminate\

It will be in Estella Courtyard on April 21st at 7pm from 10pm.

Subject: Organizing for Prison Industrial Complex Abolition Speaker event!
We are excited to announce that Saturday, April 8, the 5C Prison Abolition Collective will be joined by Amber-Rose Howard, Executive Director of the abolitionist policy organization CURB (curbprisonspending.org).
Experiencing a felony conviction as a young adult propelled Amber-Rose into a lifetime commitment of organizing against the Prison Industrial Complex and building up the power of Black people and all others impacted by state violence and racial capitalism. Come join us to hear more!
5C Prison Abolition Collective, Student
