Subject: Fundraiser for Roof Repair of a Non-Profit South LA Medical Clinic
Universal Community Health Center is a nonprofit organization that has provided quality care to underserved populations in South LA. During the recent storms, a section of the ceiling in their newly opened clinic collapsed, causing significant damage. The cost of repair is high, and any donation will help the clinic return to providing critical healthcare services to the community. Please donate to this GoFundMe to help! https://www.gofundme.com/f/uchc-oneill-clinic-ceiling-collapse<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gofundme.com%2Ff%2Fuchc-oneill-clinic-ceiling-collapse&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C346468dab9e147111eb508db346d0c67%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638161415180150319%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=WNE6aPNal5GKrit7r2Zwo%2BCxaJK3V4rwwfBFkeA83DM%3D&reserved=0>
\Terminate\
Subject: Oldenborg OLC: Earth, Ice, Bone, Blood: Discontinuity, Extinction and Permafrost in the Russian Arctic
Dr. Charlotte Wrigley, University of Stavanger (Norway), talks about how the idea of extinction takes on greater weight in the Anthropocene - the proposed new epoch that places humans as the dominant geologic agents.  Her talk considers how permafrost produces different forms of extinction by way of its becoming discontinuous - not just materially, but as an heterogenous epistemological category that has implications for all life on Earth.
Tuesday, April 4, Oldenborg dining hall @ 12:15pm
\Terminate\

Subject: WorldWE Youth 5cs "Sex Work" and the Media: The co-opting of a violent industry
Join the CMC Advocates and World without Exploitation 5C for an interactive event to address how the media has gotten the sex trade wrong, popular myths surrounding trafficking and commercial sex, prostitution policy, and a showing of a WorldWE Youth Coalition webinar. This event will be catered!

Place: Pickford Auditorium @ CMC

Subject: The Humanities Toolkit Session: Opinion Writing Workshop with Teresa Tritch
Friday, April 14 / 1-4pm / Hahn 101 (NEW LOCATION)
The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion-writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Learn more & register at bit.ly/opedwithtritch

Subject: Summer OA Coordinator Job Opportunity

Excited about OA? Looking for a summer job? Go to HANDSHAKE and apply for the summer OA Coordinator position today! We are looking for 3-4 detail-oriented students to work at the OEC this summer to plan and prepare all the details for OA trips.

$15.50/hour; 20-40 hours/week. On-campus housing included w/ meal plan.

Coordinators work 10-12 weeks during the summer, with flexibility in June/July, full-time in August. Interviews begin April 24th. See Handshake for full job details.

Subject: Accessibility in Classrooms Toolkit Survey

Hello! We are a group of students looking to improve the environment of the classroom through a disability justice framework. We are looking for stories and experiences to guide us in creating a tool kit for classroom accessibility as well as asking you on how our classrooms hinder us in certain ways.

Please fill out this survey to better inform how we can create a toolkit to help professors and students create more accessible classrooms:

Subject: Western Union (WU) Global Scholars: Scholarship Opportunity
WU Global Scholars targets rising college juniors & seniors who experience a financial hardship that may prevent the completion of their degree program. Selected scholars will receive up to $10,000 for the upcoming academic year (2023-24). Rising juniors & seniors are eligible to apply, including international students, non-citizens &/or permanent residents of the U.S., regardless of immigration status. Submission deadline is April 5, 2023, at 11:59PM. More info: https://tinyurl.com/POMWUGS23<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2FPOMWUGS23&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C9fac8c811bf04f580f2c08db2eed316a%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638155368489158717%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=88mxKh1pst%2BFD88D3i0BAqY46347qdCpcluI6TXwFlw%3D&reserved=0>.

Subject: Career Development Office - Virtual Workshop + Alumni Insights: Collecting Ecological Monitoring Data for Use in Natural Resource Management
Come learn from a Pomona '14 alum, Cassandra Owens and colleagues at Southwest Conservation Corps what it's like to be on a field crew collecting data for a long-term, large-scale, standardized vegetative resource and soil dataset. They are also actively recruiting for Ecological Monitoring Crew Members!
\Terminate\
Subject: Oldenborg - OLC: Earth, Ice, Bone, Blood: Discontinuity, Extinction and Permafrost in the Russian Arctic
Dr. Charlotte Wrigley, University of Stavanger (Norway), talks about how the idea of extinction takes on greater weight in the Anthropocene - the proposed new epoch that places humans as the dominant geologic agents. Her talk considers how permafrost produces different forms of extinction by way of its becoming discontinuous - not just materially, but as an heterogenous epistemological category that has implications for all life on Earth.
Tuesday, April 4, Oldenborg dining hall @12:15pm
\Terminate\

Subject: Humanities Toolkit Session: an Academic Press Publishing with
Wed, March 29 / 4:30pm / Crookshank, Ena Thompson Room
Interested in learning about publishing your writing with an academic press? Join us to hear practical advice from Larin McLaughlin, editorial director at Univ. of Washington Press, who draws from nearly two decades of publishing experience specializing in support for works by women of color and in critical ethnic studies. It's part of the Humanities Studio's Humanities Toolkit series.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Toolkit Session: Opinion Writing Workshop with Teresa Tritch
Friday, April 14 / 1-4pm / Estella 1021
The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Learn more & register at bit.ly/opedwithtritch.

Hello all! In mid-April, CSPH will be hosting our Public Health Symposium. Students share/present resources, organizations, news, and general information on any public health issue/event of their interest with similarly oriented peers. This semester, we are hoping to include professor participation. This is a low-stakes, community-building event, so don't be intimidated to share with us or just attend! Subject: Department of Anthropology - On Collaboration: Publishing, Design, and Anthropology

What does collaboration look like for and between publishing, graphic design, and anthropology? Join us Friday, March 24th at the Benton Museum Pavilion for a conversation between Maia Asshaq, writer, editor, and publisher of Detroit based Flint Magazine, Maya Moumne, designer and founder of Beirut based Studio Safar, and Chau Mellon Postdoctoral Fellow in Anthropology at Pomona College, Omer Shah. These different practitioners will explore the different experiences and demands of collaboration.

\Terminate\
Subject: Oldenborg OLC: Autism as Neurodiversity: Affect, Care, and Crip Aesthetics in Chinese Cinema

Hangping Xu, UCSB professor, identifies the first decade of the 21st century as a turning point by which autism representations emerged in China via social discourses and cinematic spectacles. With a focus on the autism-themed film Ocean Heaven (2010), Xu argues that cinema exploits the spectacle of autism as a family melodrama of excessive affect and uses it to address larger social anxiety about the changing political economy of care.
Monday, March 27, Oldenborg dining hall @12:15pm
\Terminate\

Subject: Humanities Toolkit Session: Publishing with an Academic Press

Wed, March 29 / 4:30pm / Crookshank, Ena Thompson Room
Interested in learning about publishing your writing with an academic press? Join us to hear practical advice from Larin McLaughlin, editorial director at Univ. of Washington Press, who draws from nearly two decades of publishing experience specializing in support for works by women of color and in critical ethnic studies. It's part of the Humanities Studio's Humanities Toolkit series.

Subject: Humanities Toolkit Session: Opinion Writing Workshop with Teresa Tritch

Friday, April 14 / 1-4pm / Estella 1021
The Humanities Studio invites students to join us for an opinion writing workshop with editor and writer Teresa Tritch. Drawing on 13 years of experience as a member of the Editorial Board of the New York Times, Tritch will address how academics can write persuasively for a broad audience, what editors are looking for, how to gain an editor's attention and how to write an effective op-ed. Learn more & register at bit.ly/opedwithtritch
\Terminate\
Subject: Inclusive Claremont - Arbol Verde Walking Tour

Join Inclusive Claremont on Saturday, March 25th at 1pm for the Arbol Verde Walking Tour. We'll start the tour at El Barrio Park, and a group of students will head to the park from Seal Court at 12:45pm. We'll hear from community leaders about the history of the Mexican-American community in Claremont, and talk specifically about how the colleges have played a role in displacement and housing injustice in this community. Subject: The CARES Office - Forensic Exams 101

Join CMC's Title IX Office and Pomona's CARES Office on Wednesday, March 29th at 5pm as we welcome Destine Teves Borrego, MSN, RN, SANE-A, SANE-P. Destine will facilitate a conversation regarding  how a forensic exam can be helpful for survivors who experienced harm, the importance of timely access & the resources available. This event will be in the Founder's Room on CMC's campus. RSVP at bit.ly/forensicexam101 and sign up for the 5pm session!

Subject: Submit a Self-Tape Audition for Moments: A BIPOC Artist's Showcase
This project is a space for BIPOC artists' to explore, create, play, learn, and join in community. The show is comprised of three core elements: music, devised work, and pre-existing work. Please submit a video of a short monologue or any form of text (poem, book, etc.) and if you want to be considered for a solo in any of the musical numbers we will do, please film yourself singing 20 - 30 seconds of your favorite song with an accompaniment track.

Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Good Jobs Versus a Post-Work Society: Diverse Meanings of Work in a Good Life
Which would be better - a society in which all adults capable of working were guaranteed a well-paid job, or a society in which people were not forced to sell their labor to live a decent life? Dive into this riveting discussion with Pitzer College Professor Claudia Strauss at the next Claremont Discourse lecture, hosted by The Claremont Colleges Library, on March 22nd at 4:15 p.m. This lecture is free and open to all. Visit 7clib.cc/CStrauss for more information.
\Terminate\

Deaf West engages artists and audiences in unparalleled theater experiences weaving ASL with spoken English. Discussion and Q&A moderated by Sage Wong-Davies, Scripps '25 and Kim Drake, Scripps associate professor of Writing and Rhetoric.

Where: Hampton Room (2nd floor of Malott)

Subject: Intercollegiate Feminist Center 'Economies of Motherhood': Reproductive Justice in a Globalizing World
Around the world, governments are placing restrictions on the reproductive rights of women and girls. Join the Pulitzer Center and Intercollegiate Feminist Center for an afternoon of conversations with journalists, scholars, and advocates who bear witness to these issues and consider ways forward.

Subject: Health Bridges - Speaker on Thursday: #DadosSalvamVidas - A COVID Dashboard case study: Bridge the digital divide in the favelas of Rio

We will host the fifth speaker in our series on health equity on Thursday, March 9 at 12:15 pm in Hahn 101. Lunch will be provided!

Pomona professor of Environmental Analysis Guillermo Douglass-Jaimes will present on his work mapping COVID-19 cases in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He will reflect on the strategies and challenges of collecting accurate health information in populations beyond the reach of the state.

Subject: Claremont-based nonprofit - the Newcomers Access Center (NAC) - Know Your Rights Workshop for Immigrants on 03/14 from 6:30 PM - 8:00 PM

The NAC, a Claremont-based nonprofit that serves immigrants and refugees, is hosting a Know Your Rights workshop on Tuesday, March 14th from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM at Claremont United Church (233 Harrison Avenue). An immigration manager and a legal representative from the International Rescue Committee of Los Angeles will be leading the workshop, and it will focus primarily on the status of pathways for Afghan and Ukrainian nationals. To attend, email office@newcomersaccesscenter.org to register.

Subject: 5C Prison Abolition Collective - *SURVEY LINK INCLUDED: Experiences with Campus Security - Seeking Responses

The 5C Prison Abolition Collective is seeking student testimonies about negative experiences with Campus Security as part of a larger movement to eliminate their presence as a policing force on campus. Please fill out this form if you are willing to have your story shared, Ideally, we would be compiling these stories as part of an audio/visual compilation. NOTE: if you already filled out our last survey, please fill this one out as well! LINK BELOW!

Subject: Free counseling for 7C survivors through new EmPOWER Center program
Through a collaboration with the Lavender Healing Collective, the EmPOWER Center is offering free, virtual, confidential, trauma-informed counseling services to 7C student survivors of sexual assault, dating/domestic violence, & stalking. Counseling is available to students of all gender identities without a long wait. To schedule, call 424.542.8880 or complete the form at lavenderhealingcollective.com/contact-us and identify yourself as a "Claremont Colleges student."

Subject: Speaker Event: Reproductive Justice and the Prison Industrial Complex with Lynn Paltrow!
Sunday, March 26! Women's Union!
We are excited to announce that Sunday, March 26, Lynn Paltrow, JD will join the 5C Prison Abolition Collective along with the Intercollegiate Feminist Center. Paltrow is the founder of Pregnancy justice and a scholar/activist specializing in issues of reproductive justice, challenging restrictions on abortion rights, and opposing the criminalization of pregnancy. Paltrow will join us remotely and the event will be held at the Women's Union at 3 pm. We hope to see you there!<3

Subject: Submit a Self-Tape Audition for Moments: A BIPOC Artist's Showcase
This project is a space for BIPOC artists' to explore, create, play, learn, and join in community. The show is comprised of three core elements: music, devised work, and pre-existing work. Please submit a video of a short monologue or any form of text (poem, book, etc.) and if you want to be considered for a solo in any of the musical numbers we will do, please film yourself singing 20 - 30 seconds of your favorite song with an accompaniment track.
\Terminate\
Subject: Oldenborg OLC: Celebration of Nowruz (Vernal Equinox / Persian New Year)
Speaker: Niloufar Shiri, Visiting Artist, Pomona College Music Department
Niloufar Shiri, a performer and composer from Tehran, Iran, will introduce Nowruz and discuss the importance of poetry to Persian culture in both music and everyday life. The presentation will feature musical selections performed by Ms. Shiri on the kamancheh, the heart-rending fiddle of classical Persian music, accompanied by Armita Salimi on tar and Milad Jahadi on tombak.
Monday March 6, Oldenborg dining hall @12:15pm
\Terminate\

Subject: 5C Hackathon - Sign up now!
Visit 5CHack.com to sign up and learn more about the 5C Hackathon! It is a 24-hour overnight event where teams of students come together to create technical (and non-technical) projects that a panel of experts will judge. Along the way, we provide snacks, games, and events to keep participants motivated and having a great time. Previous 5C Hackathoners remember the 5C Hackathon as one of their favorite college experiences! All majors & schools are welcome. Zero coding experience is required!

Subject: Wellness Taskforce-- 47 Days of Wellness - Forks Over Knives---A documentary film that can change your life!
"A film that can change your life" is what Roger Ebert said about the documentary "Forks Over Knives". The idea of food as medicine is put to the test. Can chronic disease be controlled by adopting a whole food, plant-based diet?
Come to Rose Hills Theater on Thursday March 9 from 12-1:30 to watch this thought provoking film.
Bring your own lunch - and an open mind. Light beverage service provided.

Subject: Wellness Taskforce--47 Days of Wellness - Speaker Dr.
‚ÄúDesigning an Exercise Program to Maximize Health and Well Being‚Äù with Dr. Robert Sallis, MD. Join us in conversation with the amazing Dr. Sallis on Monday, March 6, 12:10pm, Rose Hills Theater. BYO lunch and we will provide beverages and a delicious and healthy treat. Learn the science behind the value of physical activity, and how to design the most beneficial exercise program.
Dr. Sallis is a family medicine and sports medicine physician. He currently chairs the Advisory Board for Exercise

Subject: Theatre Department - THREE SISTERS SHOW THIS WEEKEND!

The Prozorov siblings have it easy...maybe too easy. After their father's death, they dream of moving back to Moscow, but when Colonel Vershinin arrives one day, he brings with him a spark of hope and the possibility of destroying everything. Written by Anton Chekhov and adapted by two-time Pulitzer Prize Finalist, Sarah Ruhl, ""Three Sisters"" depicts real experiences of hope, loneliness, and growing up.

Subject: Wellness Taskforce - Wellness and Music

Wellness Taskforce 47 Days of Wellness:  Wellness and Music
Music is a powerful influencer on an individual's life. It brings joy, healing, helps us make new friends, have fun with old friends, and is a great promoter of wellness. According to research at Johns Hopkins, listening to music can reduce anxiety, blood pressure, and pain as well as improve sleep quality, mood, mental alertness, and memory. Come to the Jazz Ensemble Open Rehearsal on Thurs., March 2, 4:15, Lyman Hall in Thatcher.

Subject: Sex Trade 101 - World Without Exploitation meeting this Tuesday!
Join World Without Exploitation Youth Coalition's 5C chapter this Tuesday, 2/28 at 7:00 pm in Smith Campus Center 217.
As we go over the basics of the sex trade - including the realities of LGBTQ+ people in the sex trade, origins of prostitution, economic coercion, consent and choice feminism, the right to exit, liberal versus socialist orientations toward the trade, and basic policy models. This is a perfect introductory meeting if you have questions about sexual exploitation and WorldWE!

Subject: Department of Asian Languages & Literatures and Asian Studies Program
Biwa: A Tradition of Japanese Narrative Music - Lecture-Demonstration by Nobuko Fukatsu - Thurs, Mar 2 / 4:15pm / Hahn 108
Interested in traditional Japanese arts and culture? Join us THIS THURSDAY (Mar 2) at 4:15pm in Hahn 108 for a talk on the Japanese traditional stringed instrument biwa, and its use in narrative music, by LA-based biwa player Nobuko Fukatsu! The talk will be followed by a performance of "Dan-no-ura" from the 13th century Tale of Heike. We hope to see you there!

Subject: TODAY, Thurs, Feb 23 / 4:30pm / Estella 1051

Join us in welcoming Janet Gyatso, Prof of Buddhist Studies at Harvard, for her talk "Being-With Animals on Planet Earth: Explorations of Animal Ethics and Phenomenologies." Gyatso will draw on modern Western & Buddhist critical theory to consider the nature of the categories of "the human" and "the animal," pointing to several problems she sees in pinning down those definitions. It's the first spring event in our Human/Nature Speakers Series.

Subject: Professor Cookbook!
It's a beautifully designed book with snacks, entrees, and sweets recipes from over 40 of our favorite 5C professors. This digital cookbook is "pay what you can" with a recommended donation of $5 per cookbook. To purchase a cookbook, please Venmo your donation to @Claremont-Project-Sunshine and fill out this Google form (https://tinyurl.com/PSunCookbook ). Proceeds go towards supporting kids in pediatric care!

Blood Drive on Thursday, March 2nd!
Sign up to donate blood in Edmunds Ballroom on Thursday, March 2nd from 8am to 8pm! All donors will receive a free $10 Visa e-gift card and free snacks.
To make an appointment, go to www.redcrossblood.org and enter sponsor code "pomcol". Each donation saves up to three lives!
Reach out to Claire with any questions.
\Terminate\
Subject: Antisemitism and Anti-Jewish Racism - A Workshop and Conversation!
Have you heard about antisemitism? How is it related to Judaism? What is Judaism? If you want to learn more, come to listen and have a conversation about antisemitism in the US and on our campus.
Led by Ayelet Kleinerman, Haverim Board Member *People from all backgrounds are welcome!!*
Pomona College --> Smith Campus Center --> Second floor --> Room 208
Tuesday, February 28th, 7:30 - 8:30 PM

Subject: Benton Museum of Art Captured Vision Art | Science Colloquium (Feb 23 & 24)
On February 23-24, the Benton Museum is hosting the Captured Vision Art|Science Colloquium, exploring the relationship between scientific technology, perspective, and the visual arts. Keynote talk by Paula Findlen, Prof. of History at Stanford, tours by artists Sheila Pinkel and Abelardo Morell, and a student art showcase. We'll have lots of food and wine!

Subject: Inclusive Claremont - Inclusive Claremont meeting 2/21!
Join Inclusive Claremont on Tuesday, February 21st at 7pm at the Motley Coffeehouse at Scripps! We'll debrief our recent events and actions for tenants' rights in Claremont, talk about next steps for supporting strong renter protections, finalize our semester plans, and build community between students and Claremont community members. No prior knowledge or experience is necessary, just come ready to learn. There will be snacks as well!
Any questions? Reach out to Gwen Tucker

Sign up here: https://forms.gle/73BHQ2MGuLtK63176<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2F73BHQ2MGuLtK63176&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C48de104dcf2b4b64bfe108db136ea852%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638125138217395076%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=zp8XC7Xe92cA5j6H23cxbIZ2q%2FSXV2YrWrjakJAO0Fg%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Health Bridges - Community Health Clinic IT and Equity
Dr. Edgar Chavez has devoted his career to providing quality healthcare to underserved communities. In 2009, he opened the Universal Community Health Center in a modest strip mall, blocks away from where he grew up in South Los Angeles. Since then, UCHC has grown to 6 locations serving thousands of families each year.
Dr. Chavez will explain how his organization uses information technology to advance health equity solutions for vulnerable Southern California communities. Sweet treats too!
\Terminate\

\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents:  Janet Gyatso on Animal Ethics, Buddhist Ethics & the Posthuman Thurs, Feb 23 / 4:30pm / Estella 1051
Join us in welcoming Janet Gyatso, Prof of Buddhist Studies at Harvard, for her talk Being-With Animals on Planet Earth: Explorations of Animal Ethics and Phenomenologies. Gyatso will draw on modern Western & Buddhist critical theory to consider the nature of the categories of "the human" and "the animal," pointing to several problems she sees in pinning down those definitions. It's the first spring event in our Human/Nature Speakers Series.
\Terminate\
Subject: Pris Ab Presents.

Join us February 17 to view Matthew Solomon's new documentary Reimagining Safety, followed by a panel with experts featured in the film. In this doc, 10 experts discuss how policing and incarceration create more harm than good, why the system persists, and what changes can be made to make everyone safe. This will kick off the Pris Ab spring speaker series and we can't wait to see you there! Feel free to reach out to 5cprisonabolition@gmail.com or on insta @5cprisonabolition with any questions :)
\Terminate\
Subject: Pris Ab Presents.

5c Pris Ab is so honored to announce that author and organizer Andrea Ritchie will be joining us on Sunday, February 19th at 3pm in the Rose Hills Theater at Pomona. She will be speaking about her life's work of organizing for women of color and against institutional violence, as well as her most recent book, No More Police: A Case for Abolition. You can learn more about this event and RSVP here: https://engage.claremont.edu/engage/event/8850150. Feel free to reach out with any questions!

Subject: CARES Office - Empowered (Free Self-Defense Class)

The Title IX and CARES Office welcome Rachel Piazza, founder of Feminist Self-Defense, for this interactive and immersive free self-defense class as part of the Pomona College Wellness Taskforce's 47 Days of Wellness! Practice holistic wellness with confidence building techniques through verbal boundary setting and finish with physical boundary setting, ground defense, and how to handle escalated scenarios.
Friday, Feb. 24th at 1:30pm in Edmunds Ballroom

Subject: Interested in a career in healthcare?

Medical Humanities is an interdisciplinary field that encourages creative modes of thinking about the culture, discourse, and history of biomedicine. It brings together the humanities, social sciences, arts, and social justice to examine the myriad causes of health disparities with the goal of improving healthcare practices and biomedical institutions. If you are interested in participating in this summer program, please complete this short survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/78ZZLKS<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.surveymonkey.com%2Fr%2F78ZZLKS&data=05%7C01%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C3d9ecb3650ce49cdfc3908db1048f7fa%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638121677825512029%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=D03zYVWsiHobI%2FVkHvEwzroVoq%2FYH4KgQoqZIpYz6Mk%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Interested in a career in healthcare?
Medical Humanities is an interdisciplinary field that encourages creative modes of thinking about the culture, discourse, and history of biomedicine. It brings together the humanities, social sciences, arts, and social justice to examine the myriad causes of health disparities with the goal of improving healthcare practices and biomedical institutions. If you are interested in participating in this summer program, please complete this short survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/78ZZLKS<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.surveymonkey.com%2Fr%2F78ZZLKS&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cd87b39f1f0234a2ac16e08db0df29a8d%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638119107843593124%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=9kjQfsc1up5JY0W6U9J6izJ6KuFJpRiEIX4v5NDRZrU%3D&reserved=0>
\Terminate\
Subject: Benton Museum of Art Captured Vision Art|Science Colloquium @ the Benton Museum (Feb 23 & 24)
On February 23-24, the Benton Museum is hosting the Captured Vision Art|Science Colloquium, exploring the relationship between scientific technology, perspective, and the visual arts. Keynote talk by Paula Findlen, Prof. of History at Stanford, tours by artists Sheila Pinkel and Abelardo Morell, and a student art showcase. We'll have lots of food and wine!

Subject: The Anthropology Dept & the Humanities Studio Present:  Summon the Muse: Developing a Culture & History Podcast with Avery Trufelman Mon, Feb 13 / 4:30pm / Argue Auditorium (Estella 1051)
The Anthropology Dept & the Humanities Studio invite Claremont Colleges students to meet and hear from Avery Trufelman, host and producer of the‚ÄØ"Articles of Interest,"‚ÄØ"The Cut," and‚ÄØ"99% Invisible"‚ÄØpodcasts. In this talk, Trufelman breaks down the specifics of how she makes the "Articles of Interest" show and what questions go into seeking out the broader narratives behind its content-how we look...and how we want to.  Join us!
\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents: Janet Gyatso on Animal Ethics, Buddhist Ethics & the PostHuman - Thurs, Feb 23 / 4:30pm / Estella 1051
Join us in welcoming Janet Gyatso, Prof of Buddhist Studies at Harvard, for her talk "Being-With Animals on Planet Earth: Explorations of Animal Ethics and Phenomenologies." Gyatso will draw on modern Western & Buddhist critical theory to consider the nature of the categories of "the human" and "the animal," pointing to several problems she sees in pinning down those definitions. It's the first spring event in our Human/Nature Speakers Series.

Subject: 5C Prison Abolition Collective - New Abolitionist Documentary Screening - Reimagining Safety - Thurs, Feb 17 - Scripps Humanities Auditorium
Join us February 17 to view Matthew Solomon's new documentary Reimagining Safety, followed by a panel with experts featured in the film. In this doc, 10 experts discuss how policing and incarceration create more harm than good, why the system persists, and what changes can be made to make everyone safe. This will kick off the Pris Ab spring speaker series and we can't wait to see you there!
Feel free to reach out to 5cprisonabolition@gmail.com or on insta @5cprisonabolition with any questions :)

Subject: Draper Center - Rooftop Garden Club - Join Us!
At Rooftop Garden, we build community between college and high school students who share a passion for learning about and caring for our environment by leading efforts in gardening, sustainability, restoration, and environmental education. Meetings will be held on Thursdays from approximately 4:15pm to 5:45pm.

Subject: Join 5C Science Bus!
Do you love science? Do you enjoy working with kids?
If so, consider volunteering with 5C Science Bus! As a volunteer, you'll co-teach weekly science lessons and lead group experiments at local elementary schools, where you'll cover everything from astronomy to forensic science to friction! The lesson plan, experiment materials, and transportation to the school will all be provided. All majors are welcome!
Sign up to teach here: https://tinyurl.com/scibus23spring<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fscibus23spring&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cdbcf60f2f8ac4ee7e96608db08760ddd%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638113075344010989%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=1UhGer0HfT3yHhO2fytMR%2BzABo%2FwGC5ijD%2BCsgvopDc%3D&reserved=0>
\Terminate\
Subject: Volunteer at Science Day!
Sign up to volunteer for Science Day! Science Day is a daylong event where students from the PUSD schools take a field trip to Harvey Mudd to perform hands-on experiments alongside 5C students and professors!
This year's theme will focus on structural design: there will be two experiments, an ""Eggstreme"" Egg Drop and a roller coaster design challenge. No experience necessary: we will walk you through exactly what to do at the training session :)
\Terminate\
Subject: Do you like working with kids? Do you want to help support patients in pediatric care?
If so, consider joining Project Sunshine! Our volunteers restore a crucial sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment and spread sunshine to children through camaraderie during emotionally and physically challenging times. Subject: 5C Photography Club - Join Us!
5C Photography Club is a new space for all photographers, beginners to veterans, film to digital, to develop and showcase their skills, as well as collaborate with fellow photographers. We also look to partner with local photographers and organizations to create impactful relations that will benefit our members and the community. Subject: Oldenborg - 2/7 12:15pm - OLC: Europe's Fires and the World's
Speaker Stephen Pyne is one of the founding historians of fire and human civilization. His most recent books include The Pyrocene: How We Created and Age of Fire, and What Happens Next and The Great Ages of Discovery. How Western Civilization Learned About a Wider World. In an earlier life he spent 15 seasons with the North Rim Longshots, a fire crew at Grand Canyon.
Check our website for more details: https://bit.ly/3Hybk1j<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3Hybk1j&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cdbcf60f2f8ac4ee7e96608db08760ddd%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638113075344010989%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=sMJFgvf4P%2FrsjFeCF7dCB09Q%2BZOmtjBhzPm2OiDL0bY%3D&reserved=0>

The 5C Prison Abolition Collective is excited to announce a series of speakers who will be sharing their work and knowledge with the Claremont Colleges this semester! Topics will range from dissecting the Prison Industrial Complex, reimagining how we view safety, reproductive justice, gender and the PIC, and much more. Our speaker series will get started Thursday, Feb 17 so look out for our upcoming announcements! Reach out to 5cprisonabolition@gmail.com or @5cprisonabolition on insta with Qs :)

Reimagining Safety - Thurs, Feb 17 - Scripps Humanities Auditorium
Join us February 17 to view Matthew Solomon's new documentary Reimagining Safety, followed by a panel with experts featured in the film. In this doc, 10 experts discuss how policing and incarceration create more harm than good, why the system persists, and what changes can be made to make everyone safe. Subject: The EmPOWER Center - Support Group for Survivors of Sexual Assault
EmPOWER Center presents an in-person, weekly Support Group for Survivors of Sexual Assault on Fridays from 1-2:30pm. Begins 2/17 at the EmPOWER Center (sign up latest by 2/15 at peacethroughprocess@gmail.com). Open to 7C students of all gender identities. Designed for students who have experienced sexual assault/abuse, whether recently or long ago. Briana Bedran, Associate MFT with the Lavender Healing Collective, facilitates this confidential group.

Subject: Art Department - Lunchtime Art Talk by Gray Wielebinski (Tuesday)
Please join us for another installment of the Art Department's Lunchtime Art Talk series! This Tuesday, Feb. 7th, at 12:20 pm Gray Wielebinski will be speaking in the Frank blue room.  Wielebinski graduated from Pomona and went on to receive an MFA from the Slade School of Fine Art in London. Wielebinski pulls inspiration from histories of mythmaking, and uses collage as a main method for creating art. We hope to see you there!

Subject: Muslim Life Program - Music event at Garrison Theatre (Al-Firdaus Ensemble)
Al Firdaus Ensemble, a group of musicians based in Spain, is performing at Garrison Theatre (Scripps) this Saturday, Feb. 11th! The group includes musicians from all around the world, creating music with the influence of Western classical, Celtic, Arabic, Turkish, Andalusi, and Flamenco music traditions. Light refreshments are provided starting 6PM, and the performance starts at 7PM.
\Terminate\
Subject: Anthropology Department - Interested in a career in healthcare?
Interested in bioethics? Consider applying to Pomona's new Medical Humanities program this summer!
Medical Humanities is an interdisciplinary field that encourages creative modes of thinking about the culture, discourse, and history of biomedicine. It brings together the humanities, social sciences, arts, and social justice to examine the myriad causes of health disparities with the goal of improving healthcare practices and biomedical institutions. If you are interested in participating in this summer program, please complete this short survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/78ZZLKS<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.surveymonkey.com%2Fr%2F78ZZLKS&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cdbcf60f2f8ac4ee7e96608db08760ddd%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638113075344010989%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=PNTlHfcEOyCQQLsslV8h5OO7FsS1ukL1XHo5kFce6P4%3D&reserved=0>
\Terminate\

Subject: Join 5C Science Bus!

Do you like science? Do you enjoy working with kids?

If so, consider volunteering with 5C Science Bus! As a volunteer, you will co-teach weekly science lessons and lead group experiments at local elementary schools, where you'll cover everything from coral reefs to clean energy to the pulmonary system! The lesson plan, experiment materials, and transportation to the school will all be provided. All majors are welcome to join!

Sign up to teach here: https://tinyurl.com/scibus23spring<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fscibus23spring&data=05%7C01%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C60d1c4ab97de4e93e5b508db054d078b%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638109600620200400%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=6JvGZknny%2BYfx5VnOBtVRUbHwigyXG9che7aNfqlMYA%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Do you like working with kids? Do you want to help support patients in pediatric care?
If so, consider joining Project Sunshine! Our volunteers restore a crucial sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment and spread sunshine to children through camaraderie during emotionally and physically challenging times. Learn more about our organization's recent initiatives on our Instagram (@psclaremontcolleges) üòä


Do you love working with children and want to engage more with communities outside Claremont? Jumpstart members volunteer at preschools in Upland & Ontario twice a week, designing our own lesson plans including songs, reading, and art. Subject: The EmPOWER Center - Weekly Support Group for Survivors of Intimate Partner Violence or Abuse
8-week virtual group for 7C students of all gender identities who have experienced dating/intimate partner violence or abuse, whether recently or long ago. The group will provide survivors with a confidential space to receive support while they work through the healing process. This EmPOWER Center group is facilitated by Eimy Estrada, an Associate Marriage and Family Therapist with House of Ruth. Tuesdays from 3-4:30pm, begins 2/21 (sign up by 2/20 at e.estrada@houseofruthinc.org<mailto:e.estrada@houseofruthinc.org>)

Subject: Join 5C Science Bus!
If so, consider volunteering with 5C Science Bus! As a volunteer, you'll co-teach weekly science lessons and lead group experiments at local elementary schools, where you'll cover everything from coral reefs to clean energy to the pulmonary system! The lesson plan, experiment materials, and transportation to the school will all be provided. All majors are welcome to join!
Sign up to teach here: https://tinyurl.com/scibus23spring<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fscibus23spring&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cf9a8087ad2884d46360808dafd76e198%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638100984269377144%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=tK2wW5oUZCFT5kwZ5hHrq%2FNKi6x8Vs7wmIF12RwpgJo%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Volunteer with the Weekly Writing Workshop!
If so, consider applying to be a writing mentor for the Weekly Writing Workshop!  Our workshop aims to foster confidence in writing through individualized support, community, and carefully crafted instruction. \Terminate\
Subject: Lydia Pelot-Hobbs - We Deserve Better: Contesting Racialized Sexual and Gender Policing  Thursday, January 26, 2023
Ena Thompson room, Crookshank Hall 108

This talk examines the New Orleans grassroots organization BreakOUT!'s We Deserve Better campaign to illuminate the centrality of policing racialized gender and sexuality in the contemporary carceral state and how struggles over everyday criminalization have served as a pivot point for post-Katrina New Orleans.

\Terminate\
Subject: Looking for a history class this semester?


Why does the modern world exist as it does and what makes it 'modern'? This introduction to the origin of the modern world focuses on the cultural transferences and translations between Europe and the rest of the world between roughly 1400 and 1815 and the cultural, intellectual, political, religious, and social transformations that shaped these encounters.

Subject: Benton Museum of Art at Pomona College Art After Hours x KSPC 88.
Gingee is a Filipino American producer, percussionist, vocalist and DJ captivating audiences with performances that combine the rhythms of Filipino kulintang gongs and other percussion with genres such as hip hop, electronic, global bass and funk.
She's played at Grand Performances, SXSW, Levitt Pavilion, Globalquerque, Coachella, Eagle Rock Music Festival. Check out her art collective Magic Garage and her 4-part EP series "Solstice/Equinox."

Subject: Benton Museum of Art- Salon Series: Cut for Time: Curating and Other Editorial Processes
Friday, January 27, 4:15-5:30 pm
In this first installment of the 2023 Salon Series we will look at art works that made it as far as the final checklist, but did not make it into an exhibition. We will discuss the ins and outs of planning, editorial decision-making, and various modes of curating.
Please join assistant curator of collections Solomon Salim Moore for this intimate monthly gathering to look closely at a selection of art from Benton's vaults over festive libations and cheese!

Subject: Art Department Lunch Art Talk - TIFFANY CHOW
Please join us for Pomona's Studio Art Department's first Lunch Art Talk series! The first one will be at 12:20 PM in Frank's Blue Room on January 26 2023, featuring artist Tiffany Chow. Pui Tiffany Chow's practice centers on drawing and painting, Pui explores abstraction of familiar motifs such as the female body through the distortion of color and form. Her work is a pastiche of different modes, feelings, and approaches - referencing and questioning Western painting traditions.

Subject: Audition for MACHINAL this weekend!

Inspired by a sensationalized murder trial, Machinal follows a woman trapped in the roles patriarchal society forces upon her. This haunting tale explores her futile struggle to take control of her own life in a distant era that eerily parallels our own.

Auditions are Friday (1/20) 4-8pm, Saturday (1/21) 11:30am-3:30pm. Callbacks will be Sunday 1/22 from 12-4pm.

Find all the relevant deets here: https://linktr.ee/5CPerformingArts<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flinktr.ee%2F5CPerformingArts&data=05%7C01%7Csfaa2021%40MYMAIL.POMONA.EDU%7C22346a47773547e32c1908dafa47e040%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638097483864902481%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=3gzu%2BAMvmA4gGj%2B3UC%2BvO8T25rPhZkmwTeK4rrYm0w4%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Celebrate Love Data Week 2023 with the Library's Poster Contest!
We are excited to announce the Library's Love Data Week 2023 Poster Contest, which is open to all students of The Claremont Colleges. Posters are meant to embody Love Data Week's 2023 theme to help inspire the use of data to bring about changes that matter, such as policy change, environmental change, social change, etc. Winners will receive a gift card and have their artwork put on display in the Library's newly launched Digital Scholarship Collaboratory. Subject: ESL+ Program: Build Relationships with Pomona Staff and more!
The English as a Second Language (ESL+) Tutoring Program offers staff at Pomona College an opportunity to improve their English speaking, writing, reading, and computer literacy skills through one-on-one weekly meetings with students. The program is a great opportunity for staff and students to build valuable relationships and learn from each other.

If you are interested in volunteering next semester, please fill out this form: https://forms.gle/1t96WYy72ZCjhMvT8<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2F1t96WYy72ZCjhMvT8&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cb50bfacfee97439365ce08dad9458f41%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638061190014278842%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=NnE%2FRJJ8G%2Fq09G5AT7rGhYmXP%2FKA%2B2sB30wGFl3u%2BSQ%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: essay, the Pomona Center for Writing, Speaking and the Image's official publication, is looking for submissions from first-year and transfer students!

At essay, we celebrate all parts of the writing process, considering works from all sorts of disciplines and genres. This year, we'd like you to submit the writing that feels significant to you, along with a 250-word reflection, on the process of writing your piece and how it relates to our theme, "the background." Reflections will be published in the journal alongside your submission.

Submissions will close at 11:59 p.m January 5th. Submit your work here: https://forms.gle/vKra3QJeN7a6owcY7<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FvKra3QJeN7a6owcY7&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Ca942d7e5cc3c43161cba08dad6e82d5f%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638058589920017369%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=gYANZEBTl3PHWk6rM35l%2BWBR%2BnrX26pNpQp0QkZ3TDI%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Jewish?
Jewish? Sophomore / above? Join a diverse global cohort of students this summer in Tel Aviv for a 10-week internship and fellowship program. Work at major Israeli startups, global sustainability, tech, science, and finance firms. Learn from Jewish and Arab leaders, activists, and government officials. Be paired one-on-one with an Israeli peer, and connect with Jews from around the world.

Subject: Grace Park, Deputy Director for Japan Policy in the Department of Defense, for is our guest for our last Pizza & Politics event of the semester!

Subject: Women in Security (WIS) Fellowship Speaker Series.
Grace Park, Deputy Director for Japan Policy in the Department of Defense, is coming to Claremont for the second part of the WIS speaker series. Meet her this Friday from 10-11 am at Carnegie 107.

Park will talk about her career experience working political-military issues and how that has gotten her to where she is at the Office of the Secretary of Defense to advance U.S. national security interests. Q&A will be conducted throughout to discuss career paths into federal government service.

Subject: Do you speak an uncommonly taught language?
Pomona LGCS is looking for a student to participate in LGCS 125 Field Methods in Linguistics, a class where 10-15 students and the professor will try to learn and describe your language!
Spring 23, Mondays OR Wednesdays 2:45-4, plus 3-4 additional meetings per week scheduled around your availability (with small groups of students, not full class meetings).

No teaching necessary. Please get in touch with Prof.Toni Cook at toni.cook@pomona.edu to see if you're a match!

Subject: HHI x EcoReps  -  Final Walker Flea Market!
The Hunger and Houselessness Initiative (HHI) is collaborating with the EcoReps to host the final Walker Flea Market of 2022! Alongside the market, we'll be holding a donation drive for items needed by unhoused folks in the area!

Donations must be new or gently used, and acceptable items include tents, sleeping bags, warm clothes, blankets, pillows, reusable water bottles, tote bags, backpacks, rain gear, and hygiene/health products. For more details, check out the EcoReps Instagram!

Subject: Claremont PEACE  -  Psychedelic Neuroscience Speaker Dr.
Dr. Daniel Kelly, neuroscientist, neurosurgeon, and Founder/Director of the Pacific Neuroscience Institute in Santa Monica, will be speaking about his research into psychedelics for treating mental disorders. Join us this Friday (December 2nd) 12-1pm at Seaver Commons 104 to learn about modern psychedelic research, clinical applications of psychedelics for mental health-related issues, and starting a career in clinical neuroscience. There will be a Q&A after so bring questions!

Subject: Jewish?

Jewish? Sophomore / above? Join a diverse global cohort of students this summer in Tel Aviv for a 10-week internship and fellowship program. Work at major Israeli startups, global sustainability, tech, science, and finance firms. Learn from Jewish and Arab leaders, activists, and government officials. Be paired one-on-one with an Israeli peer, and connect with Jews from around the world.

Subject: Jumpstart is hiring for the 22-23 school year!

Do you love working with children and want to engage more with communities outside Claremont? Jumpstart members volunteer at preschools in Upland & Ontario twice a week, designing our own lesson plans including songs, reading, and art. Apply online @https://application.jstart.org/ or email jumpstart@pitzer.edu<mailto:jumpstart@pitzer.edu> for any questions.

Here are the session hours this year: (you must be able to make one of these time slots)
M/W 8:30 - 11:30 am
M/W 1 - 4 pm
T/Th 8:30 - 11:30 am
T/Th 1 - 4 pm

Subject: 5C Identities Abroad Conversations and Student Panel

Are you wondering how your unique social identities shift and change during your time abroad when you engage with different cultures, ideas, and communities?

Please come to the McConnell Living Room (Pitzer) on Friday, December 2 from 1:00-2:00 p.m. to listen to 5C students (including Pomona) who have studied abroad in locations across the globe. There will be lively conversations on how to navigate the intersectionalities of one's identity abroad.

Subject: Discussion on the oneness of religion

The 5C Baha'i club will be hosting a discussion about the oneness of religion on Tuesday, Nov 22nd, 7pm at the McAlister Center. We will discuss questions such as: What aspects of religion change over time, and why? Do religions share a common foundation? Snacks will be provided!

Subject: Sagehens Abroad: Student Stories From Around the World (Study Abroad Podcast) Episode 19 ‚úà

New podcast episode: Camille Molas '21 - Edinburgh, Scotland (Fall 2019) available at: bit.ly/idpopodcast

Join host Mikaela Nishida '21, a mathematics major, as she interviews Camille Molas '21, a physics major, about her semester abroad on the Pomona College Program at University of Edinburgh. Mikaela and Camille have an enlightening conversation about the benefits of studying on a Pomona Program, how she learned more about Scottish history and culture and ways to engage in university clubs.

Subject: The Department of History, Environmental Analysis program, Latin American Studies program, Pacific Basin Institute, and Humanities Studio  -  The Workshop on the New Culinary Hyperlocalism

A new culinary hyperlocalism has been emerging along the Pacific Rim over the last decade, inspired by the nouvelle cuisine, the Slow Food Movement and the New Nordic Cuisine. Our workshop will explore this movement with the help of a scholar researching it in Peru, a farmer practicing it in Northern California, and a chef cooking it in Hawai‚Äôi. Feel free to drop in and out. Open to the public. A reception will conclude the workshop.

Subject: The Student Life - Join Professional Journalists for an Inclusive Storytelling

Join the Pulitzer Center and The Student Life newspaper for a workshop on equitable storytelling, from pitch to publication. Grantees Pendarvis Harshaw and Brandon Tauszik will talk about their multimedia project Facing Life. The project was supported by the Pulitzer Center and was published in the Los Angeles Times.

Subject: The Pulitzer Center - 'Life After Life' Panel and Presentation

Facing Life follows the lives of eight people recently released from California prisons. Harshaw is a journalist, author, and educator. Tauszik is a Los Angeles-based photographer and filmmaker. Romarilyn Ralston, a Black feminist prison abolitionist scholar and executive director of Project Rebound at Cal State Fullerton, will join them for a panel discussion following the presentation.

Subject: Pomona College Women's Union Lunch Nov 17 - "Centering Care: Transformative Justice on Campus"

Wondering what transformative justice is?  Wondering if there could be an alternative to punishment for infractions in the student handbook?

Join us for a conversation with Mark Golub (Scripps, Politics Dept), Sophie Adler (Pitzer '23) and Sonya Hadley (Scripps '23), discussing the meaning of Transformative Justice as a practice of care and alternative to carceral understandings of inter-personal harm.  Come for lunch and learn more about how to get involved.  Noon, upstairs, Walker lounge.

Subject: Oldenborg  -  OLC: 2022 Yidan Endowed Fund Recipients 11/14 12:15pm
Grant recipients share their experiences engaging in summer learning opportunities. Through the Yidan Endowed Fund for Transformative Learning Opportunities for the Study of Asia, the Oldenborg Center supports summer experiential learning opportunities that engage deeply with Asia and Asian cultures. Performance-based workshops, intensive language learning, community engagement, master classes, and research (both domestic and international), are among the types of projects that can be considered.

Subject: Oldenborg  -  OLC: 2022 Oldenborg Grant Recipients 11/16 12:15pm
Grant recipients share their experiences engaging in intensive language study programs this past summer.
In Summer 2022 the Oldenborg Grant funded two students to engage in intensive language study. In 2023 the Oldenborg Center will resume its pre-pandemic practice of having the grant offer financial support to help cover expenses for summer international research for a senior thesis or senior exercise. Pomona students from all disciplines are welcome to apply.

Subject: Mental Illness Education and MIND Lab Attitudes Study Want to learn about schizophrenia?

Recruiting participants for MIND Lab study! If you are interested, you can contact this email: mindlab@pomona.edu<mailto:mindlab@pomona.edu> If you are a Pomona Intro Psych Student, sign up on SONA. Cannot participate if you have taken or are taking an upper-level psychology course (anything beyond Intro Psych) or if you participated last semester. Participants can receive $20-$30 in compensation or 2 research credits for Intro Psych and up to $10.

Mon, Nov 7 / 4:30pm / Estella 1021

Subject: Dance Department - Soundbath 7pm Thursday (11/10) at Pendleton Dance Studio

A Sound Bath is an immersive experience where gongs, tingsha, crystal and/ or Tibetan singing bowls, or other instruments are played with the intention of providing relaxation and an overall feeling for well-being for the listener.

Wear comfortable clothes. Bring socks and/ or a blanket if you tend to get cold, yoga mat, water bottle, pillow, eye covering.

Capacity is limited to 70 participants. Please arrive early, no late admittance.
Email: john.pennington@pomona.edu<mailto:john.pennington@pomona.edu> to reserve a spot.

Subject: OLC: Revising International Peacemaking: Learning from Negotiating with the Lord's Resistance Army

Join us for a lunch talk by Mareike Shomerus (Vice President, Busara Center in Nairobi) who will be exploring the insights gathered from the Juba Peace Talks between the Lord's Resistance Army and the Ugandan Government in 2006.

Co-sponsored with the International Relations Program at Pomona College

Subject: Jewish?
Jewish? Sophomore or above? Join a diverse global cohort of students this summer in Tel Aviv for a 10-week internship and fellowship program. Work at major Israeli startups, global sustainability, tech, science, and finance firms. Learn from Jewish and Arab leaders, activists, and government officials. Be paired one-on-one with an Israeli peer, and connect with Jews from around the world.

INFO SESSION INTEREST FORM: bit.ly/5c_israel_internship

Subject: Mental Illness Education and MIND Lab Attitudes Study Want to learn about schizophrenia?

Recruiting participants for MIND Lab study! If you are interested, you can contact this email: mindlab@pomona.edu<mailto:mindlab@pomona.edu> If you are a Pomona Intro Psych Student, sign up on SONA. Cannot participate if you have taken or are taking an upper-level psychology course (anything beyond Intro Psych) or if you participated last semester. Participants can receive $20-$30 in compensation or 2 research credits for Intro Psych and up to $10.

Subject: The Humanities Studio Toolkit Session:  Joining a Broader Conversation: Writing for Popular Media

Mon, Nov 7 / 4:30pm / Estella 1021

Claremont Colleges students are invited to join Daniel Pollack-Pelzner, author of an upcoming biography of Lin-Manuel Miranda, for a presentation & discussion about turning scholarly smarts into glossy-magazine and trade-press publications. Pollack-Pelzner's writing has appeared in the New Yorker, The Atlantic, the New York Times, & other national media outlets. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series of practical interviews & workshops.

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents: Laura Kaplan on Politics, Activism & Transformation

Join us in welcoming Laura Kaplan, author of "The Story of Jane: The Legendary Underground Feminist Abortion Service," for a conversation about politics, transformation & activism with Pomona Chair of Politics Amanda Hollis-Brusky.

Kaplan was a member of the Jane Collective and appears in the HBO documentary "The Janes." It is the third talk in our Human|Nature Speakers Series. Learn more at bit.ly/hshumnat

Subject: Dance Department - Soundbath 7pm Thursday (11/10) at Pendleton Dance Studio

A Sound Bath is an immersive experience where gongs, tingsha, crystal and/ or Tibetan singing bowls, or other instruments are played with the intention of providing relaxation and an overall feeling for well-being for the listener.

Wear comfortable clothes. Bring socks and/ or a blanket if you tend to get cold, yoga mat, water bottle, pillow, eye covering.

Capacity is limited to 70 participants. Please arrive early, no late admittance.
Email: john.pennington@pomona.edu<mailto:john.pennington@pomona.edu> to reserve a spot.

Subject: Claremont Buddhism Film Screening: Marcel the Shell with Shoes On!

Subject: REUTERS photographer Lunch talk @Oldenborg
Former Reuters Chief Photographer of China, Ed Nachtrieb, will speak in person about witnessing and photographing the Tiananmen Square Massacre in 1989, as well as modern attempts to cast doubt on whether the massacre happened, even in the US.

Nov 3 (Thur) 12:15pm @Oldenborg Dining (edit from past chirps: there IS lunch provided)
Hosted by the East Asian Political Society (EAPS) & Oldenborg
\Terminate\
Subject: Film photos, Reuters Journalism in the 80s
For specifics on photojournalism, film photography, covering events in a foreign country, and an in person Q&A with former Reuters Chief Photographer in China Ed Nachtrieb, come this Thursday! Mr Nachtrieb smuggled film out of Tibet to raise awareness of the independence movement, witnessed and photographed the Tiananmen Square Massacre, amongst other key historical events. Hosted by the East Asian Political Society (EAPS).

Subject: Submit Your Matriculate Application by THIS Sunday 11/6 (Extended Deadline)!
Matriculate is a college access non-profit that supports high-achieving, low/moderate-income high school students to apply and enroll in a best-fit college by pairing students with Advising Fellows, who serve as mentors through the college application process. Matriculate provides the training and support needed to support students virtually and learn about college access. We are currently recruiting students to serve as Advising Fellows at Pomona.

Apply at https://bit.ly/3B8YUtz<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3B8YUtz&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7Cba805cb2806044d83f0c08dabdc32f0f%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638030943265023623%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=612MVqLnFfthTOG23SkSb%2FtvzKwPu1ZYy7G8mdYzXmA%3D&reserved=0> by 11/6!

Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library  -  Map Monday
Have questions about GIS? Then drop by The Claremont Colleges Library's Map Monday session on November 14 between 2pm - 4pm.
You can also check out demonstrations of new GIS tools and approaches. All skill levels are encouraged and welcome!

Learn more and sign up for this online session: 7clib.cc/MapMon.
Did you know? A geographic information system (GIS) creates, manages, analyzes and maps a wide array of data types.

Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library  -  Celebrating Filipino American History Exhibit
Join The Claremont Colleges Library in Celebrating Filipino American History - this exhibit at the Asian Library aims to present Filipino Americans' cultural heritages and regional stories, showcasing a range of Filipino linguistic texts and primers of religion, history and literature, as well as documents and photographs depicting life and work of Filipino Americans in the United States.

Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library  -  New Special Collections & Archives Exhibit Begins November 16
An upcoming exhibit (beginning November 16) by The Claremont Colleges Library will highlight the life and work of Barbara Drake, Gabriele√±o/Tongva Elder and educator. It documents her role as a cultural ambassador in local schools, museums and cultural heritage organizations where she worked tirelessly to introduce people of all ages ‚Äúto seeing the natural world in different ways‚Äù and played a key role in Tongva cultural revitalization. Stay tuned for more info!

Subject: 5C Deferred MBA Panel üéì

The Pomona CDO and CMC Career Services Office are jointly hosting a virtual panel for current 5C students considering deferred MBA programs. Deferred MBA programs are unique programs where students apply to business school in the senior year of undergrad, with the intention of matriculating 2+ years later, gaining additional life and work experience during those 2+ years.

5:30 p.m. | Nov. 1

Subject: Reuters Photojournalist presents: ONE BEST

For specifics on photojournalism, film photography, covering events in a foreign country, and an in person Q&A with former Reuters Chief Photographer in China Ed Nachtrieb, come this Thursday! Mr Nachtrieb smuggled film out of Tibet to raise awareness of the independence movement, witnessed and photographed the Tiananmen Square Massacre, amongst many other events. Hosted by the East Asian Political Society (EAPS).

Subject: Asian American Mentorship Program Untold Stories

Subject: Harvey Mudd Nelson Speaker Series - Harvey Mudd "Climate Storytellers Speaker Series: Ayana E.
"What If We Get It Right?" on Nov. 2 (Both online/in-person attendance options.)

Join us for a moderated discussion with Ayana Johnson as she shares her experiences as both a climate storyteller and a gatherer of climate stories. We will explore her professional arc from academic science to policy, advocacy and climate communication, and hear her thoughts on how racism derails our efforts at climate action. She will help us imagine what our climate future could look like if we get things right.

To let us know you are coming to the lecture, RSVP at alumni.hmc.edu/nelson22-ayana

Subject: Claremont Humans Versus Zombies Club Event

This semester's game of Humans versus Zombies is running from Nov. 8th to Nov. 12th! You can sign up on this link: tinyurl.com/hvzfall22 or at the dining halls next week, and join our discord here: discord.gg/334vFpBaW6.

Humans versus Zombies is a weeklong game of survival tag where humans are tasked with defending themselves from the ever growing horde of zombies trying to tag and convert them. Players can also compete in daily minigame missions to earn upgrades for their teams.

Subject: Oldenborg Center  -  OLC: Rights to the City: Volunteering, Infrastructures and Citizen-making
Thursday, October 27, 4:15pm @Oldenborg Dining Hall ~ Coffee and light pastries will be served

This talk examines a dimension of citizenship, which the speaker, Ka-ming Wu, calls infrastructural citizen making, in contemporary.
Ka-ming Wu, trained as a cultural anthropologist, has taken up ethnographic research to examine the cultural politics of state and society, waste, and most recently, volunteering and infrastructure in contemporary China.

TODAY Thurs, Oct 27 / 7pm / Rose Hills Theatre

Trinidad is a naturalist with roots in North East L.A. who hosts LAist Studio's podcast ‚ÄúHuman/Nature‚Äù & directs the Audubon Center at Debs Park. It's the second talk in the Humanities Studio's Human|Nature Speakers Series.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents: Walking Tour of Campus with Urban Naturalist Marcos Trinidad
Fri, Oct 28 / 10am / Meet at the fountain in Stanley Quad
Join a walking tour of campus with urban naturalist Marcos Trinidad. Starting at 10am in Stanley Quad (the courtyard shared by Pearsons, Mason & Crookshank Halls), enjoy an hour of meandering through campus, noticing fascinations of local & imported nature & their interplay with the built environment. Trinidad, who grew up in LA & now calls the IE home, hosts NPR's ‚ÄúHuman/Nature‚Äù podcast and runs the Audubon Center at Debs Park. Join us!

Subject: The Humanities Studio Toolkit Session:  Joining a Broader Conversation: Writing for Popular Media
Mon, Nov 7 / 4:30pm / Estella 1021
Claremont Colleges students are invited to join Daniel Pollack-Pelzner, author of an upcoming biography of Lin-Manuel Miranda, for a presentation & discussion about turning scholarly smarts into glossy-magazine and trade-press publications. Pollack-Pelzner's writing has appeared in the New Yorker, The Atlantic, the New York Times, & other national media outlets. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series of practical interviews & workshops.

Saturday 10/29 at 11:30pm AT CMC Pickford Auditorium (in the Bauer)

Subject: The Humanities Studio Presents: Marcos Trinidad on Nature & City Life

This Thurs, Oct 27 / 7pm / Rose Hills Theatre

Join the Humanities Studio in welcoming Marcos Trinidad for a conversation about nature & city life with Pomona College EA coordinator and prof. of politics Heather Williams. Trinidad is a naturalist with roots in North East L.A. who hosts LAist Studio's podcast "Human/Nature" & directs the Audubon Center at Debs Park. Subject: The Humanities Studio Toolkit Session:  Joining a Broader Conversation: Writing for Popular Media

Mon, Nov 7 / 4:30pm / Estella 1021

Claremont Colleges students are invited to join Daniel Pollack-Pelzner, author of an upcoming biography of Luis Manuel Miranda, for a presentation & discussion about turning scholarly smarts into glossy-magazine and trade-press publications. Pollack-Pelzner's writing has appeared in the New Yorker, The Atlantic, the New York Times, & other national media outlets. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series of practical interviews & workshops.

Subject: Pomona College ITS -  HELP!

Apologies in advance. An ITS secret project funded by Raytheon, the Computer Science Department, and the Claremont Independent has gone bad. Our proprietary artificial intelligence technology has seemingly reached singularity and has the ability to spread far beyond our control. Luckily it seems benevolent at the moment, however, everyone should be on the lookout for evil robots roaming campus in case they turn against us. If you see something, say something.

Subject: The CARES Office - Releasing through Ceramics

Join the Campus Advocates of the Pomona College CARES Office and Scripps Professor, Jasmine Baetz, for this 2-part series event on Oct. 27th and Nov. 3rd at 5pm. We will create pottery and work directly with clay. The creation will act as a form of healing to reconnect yourself with your autonomy, confidence and sense of safety. The event will be held at the ceramics studio in the Lincoln Ceramics Art Building. Enjoy free boba as well!

Seats are limited. RSVP at bit.ly/healingceramics

Subject: East Asian Political Society of the Claremont Colleges (EAPS)  - How I Report on the Russian Invasion: A Conversation with a Ukrainian Journalist (w/ Anna Romandash)

EAPS is hosting our next speaker event with Anna Romandash, an award-winning journalist from Ukraine. In the current Russo-Ukrainian War, she collects evidence and testimonies from victims of the Russian attack, occupation, and war crimes to bring the perpetrators to justice. Come and listen to her experiences reporting on her home under attack.

Date & Time: Oct 25th (Tues) 7 pm
Location: Edmunds 101 (Pomona campus)

Subject: Are you a first-gen and/or low-income woman looking for a clouty paid summer internship?
Join PhelpsForward, a FREE career development program aimed towards helping first-gen low-income women navigate the finance industry and help you find paid internships! We are currently accepting applications from first years and sophomores. You don't have to know anything about finance to join!

Subject: Jewish?

Join a diverse global cohort of students this summer in Tel Aviv for a 10-week internship and fellowship program.
Work at major Israeli startups, global sustainability, tech, science, and finance firms.
Learn from Jewish and Arab leaders, activists, and government officials.
Be paired one-on-one with an Israeli peer, and connect with Jews from around the world.

Subject: Apply for the President's Sustainability Fund!
Do you have an idea to make Pomona more sustainable? The President's Sustainability Fund provides funding for student projects that address sustainability challenges. PSF projects can be infrastructure/operational improvements for the campus or non-infrastructure initiatives such as research projects or events. Up to $7,500 is available each year to fund student proposals and research which advance sustainability on campus.
For information on how to apply, email sustainability@pomona.edu<mailto:sustainability@pomona.edu>.

We are proud to announce that our offices have secured capybaras for Capybara Day! Subject: CARES Office  -  Sound Bath & Meditation - TODAY!
Join us TODAY for a sound bath, meditation and conversation, led by Laura Purington from Women Rise, Psychological and Wellness Center. We will learn the impact of trauma, the power of meditation, and the healing of a sound bath. We will lay on the carpeted floor but you may need additional cushion to feel more comfortable. Feel free to bring your own blankets, pillows, yoga mat, and anything else to make you feel most relaxed!

RSVP is required. Reserve your spot at bit.ly/Pomonasoundbath

Subject: Spotlight Musical Theatre  -  HOME: The BIPOC Musical Showcase
HOME is a musical showcase completely composed of BIPOC students. The goal with this showcase is not only to highlight the struggle BIPOC artists endure on a daily basis, but to also allow the audience to empathize with some of the other human emotions we all experience such as: love, joy, and heartbreak.

Dates: Friday 10/21 at 8, Saturday 10/22 at 2 and 8, Sunday 10/23 at 2
Location: Large Studio at Seaver Theatre (Masks Required, Free Entry, First-Come, First-Serve)

Subject: Submit Your Matriculate Application by THIS Sunday 10/23!
Matriculate is a college access non-profit that supports high-achieving, low/moderate-income high school students to apply and enroll in a best-fit college by pairing students with Advising Fellows, who serve as mentors through the college application process. Matriculate provides the training and support needed to support students virtually and learn about college access. We are currently recruiting students to serve as Advising Fellows at Pomona.
Apply at https://bit.ly/3B8YUtz by 10/23<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3B8YUtz%2520by%252010%2F23&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C150dc9d31e5c4043257f08dab15c46c6%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638017307118833678%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=hw28AK%2FbJZegtwS6VjekRMZ6gVciHxHLXJ0kTd6dlJA%3D&reserved=0>!

Subject: CARES Office-Sound Bath & Meditation
Join us for a sound bath, meditation and conversation, led by Laura Purington from Women Rise, Psychological and Wellness Center. Together, we will learn the impact of trauma, the power of meditation, and the healing of a sound bath. We will lay on the carpeted floor but you may need additional cushion to feel more comfortable. Feel free to bring your own blankets, pillows, yoga mat, and anything else to make you feel most relaxed!
RSVP is required. Reserve your spot at bit.ly/Pomonasoundbath

Subject: The Great California Shake Out
At 10:40 a.m. on October 20, 2022, the Pomona College community will "Drop, Cover, and Hold On" in The Great California ShakeOut, the world's largest earthquake drill ever!  Major earthquakes may happen anywhere you live, work, or travel. The ShakeOut is our chance to practice how to protect ourselves, and for everyone to become prepared. The goal is to prevent a major earthquake from becoming a catastrophe for our community.

Subject: The Humanities Studio Toolkit Session: Joining a Broader Conversation: Writing for Popular Media
Mon, Nov 7 / 4:30pm / Estella 1021
Claremont Colleges students are invited to join Daniel Pollack-Pelzner, author of an upcoming biography of Luis Manuel Miranda, for a presentation & discussion about turning scholarly smarts into glossy-magazine and trade-press publications. Pollack-Pelzner's writing has appeared in the New Yorker, The Atlantic, the New York Times, & other national media outlets. It's part of our Humanities Toolkit series of practical interviews & workshops.

Asian-American Resource Center-FLI APIDA Story Circle
The FLIGHT committee is holding a story circle on Saturday, October 29th from 1-3 PM in the AARC.  We plan to center the often invisibilized narratives of those who identify as both FLI & APIDA. We hope our story circle provides a safe, welcoming, and brave space to tell your stories. We also hope to be able to lean on each other's strength and empower each other through the rest of the semester. This story circle is limited to 15 participants. RSVP: https://tinyurl.com/fall22storycircle<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Ffall22storycircle&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C150dc9d31e5c4043257f08dab15c46c6%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638017307118833678%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=PuYTeQq7iCO%2B0WK7eNOQ%2FT2T6JjwLq0UWcL7itsYSPc%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Claremont Discourse Presents Prof.
Join The Claremont Colleges Library on October 19 at 4:15 p.m. for a talk by Scripps College professor Dr. Jih-Fei Cheng titled, "From Coolie to Ku'er: Racial Capitalism, Queer of Color Critique, and the Production of Pork and Surplus Value in Taiwan". Dr. Cheng will examine how the "coolie" laborer and pork trades became emblems of the post-slavery "free market system" under global industrialization. This Claremont Discourse lecture is free and open to everyone. More: 7clib.cc/JFCheng.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Los Angeles Archives Bazaar
Come see The Claremont Colleges Library's very own Special Collections team at the 17th Annual Los Angeles Archives Bazaar at USC on Saturday, October 22 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. The event is free, open to the public and offers a one-stop opportunity to interact with dozens of Southern California history-related archives from large institutions and private collectors, as well as participate in interesting workshops and discussions. More: laassubject.org/archives-bazaar.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Mormon Mexican History Exhibit
The Claremont Colleges Library invites you to check out the most extensive, publicly accessible collection in the world of Mormon history among Spanish-speaking Latter-day Saints in the Americas. The "Unboxing the Fernando R. & Enriqueta Gomez Mormon Mexican History Collection" exhibit has been extended to run through October. It features a wide range of materials on the history of various Mormon churches in Mexico, including congregational records, mission records and more: 7clib.cc/MMHExhibit.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library Filipino American History Exhibit
Celebrate Filipino American history, cultural heritage and regional stories with The Claremont Colleges Library through Nov. 30 at its newest exhibit at the Asian Library. Of particular note are colorful and artistic book covers vividly depicting a variety of early Filipino social and cultural life. Additionally, materials in Filipino languages were published by indigenous printers and bookshops in Manila and throughout the Philippines (19th to early 20th century). More: 7clib.cc/FAHMexbt.
\Terminate\
Subject: The Claremont Colleges Library It Really Is a River Exhibit
Be sure to check out the "It Really is a River" photographic exhibit at the LA Central Library, now through January 22, 2023. The exhibit pairs historic images of the river with contemporary photographs from the LA River X collection to explore some of the river's many character traits. This exhibit was helped made possible thanks to an innovative collaboration between Pomona College, The Claremont Colleges Library and LA River X. Learn more at library.claremont.edu.
\Terminate\

Subject: Agave Review: Call for Submissions
Agave Review is currently accepting submissions of prose, poetry, creative nonfiction, and visual art to our eighth issue. This issue's theme is FLUSH; we invite you to submit work that engages with the experience of flush-whether it be through that familiar sense of self-consciousness, the growth of a new season, or even the sound of your morning routine.

We are accepting both themed and unthemed pieces. Submit your work here by Nov 17: https://tinyurl.com/agave-flushed<https://nam10.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2Fagave-flushed&data=05%7C01%7Cstudent_information%40listserv.pomona.edu%7C1053e653dd734ec0ddf508daad3c8df3%7C817f590439044ee8b3a5a65d4746ff70%7C0%7C0%7C638012772831333706%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=EzrbwlnGuVFqQ0MNf5kd65jVf%2BvIH%2BET4AK433sDk4w%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Want Legal Experience?
SCAS is the only organization in California focused on helping people navigate the small claims court system. Our work is conducted on a pro bono basis: we offer free phone and email consultations. Volunteering with SCAS is an opportunity to become familiar with the legal system while helping clients. No prior legal experience is necessary.

Info sessions at Scripps Vita Nova 100: Oct 7 - 2-3pm, Oct 10 - 5:30-6:30pm, Oct 14 - 2-3pm

Subject: Are you a first-gen and/or low-income woman looking for a clouty paid summer internship?

Join PhelpsForward, a FREE career development program aimed towards helping first-gen low-income women navigate the finance industry and help you find paid internships! We are currently accepting applications from first years and sophomores. You don't have to know anything about finance to join! To apply, please email Alicia Ames at aames@phelpsforward.com<mailto:aames@phelpsforward.com> with a quick introduction covering your academic and career interests.

Subject: Participate in an HCI study and receive $15!

The Pomona Human Computer Interaction Lab is running a study on collaborative art, and we are recruiting participants. If you are over the age of 18, have normal vision without glasses (contacts are fine, though!), do not have a history of epilepsy, and would be comfortable with drawing together with another participant (no art experience needed!), sign up to participate in the study at this link: bit.ly/hci-draw. Compensation is $15 and the study is expected to last 1 hour.
